September 8, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant you may expend an amount of $8.00 for whitewashing at the Assiniboine Indian Day School.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Booth,
Indian Agent,
Moose Jaw, Sask.
Ottawa, September 13th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to requisition dated May 26th, for supplies for the Assiniboine Indian Day School, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 60 bars laundry soaps
- 60 " Lifebuoy soaps
- 12 yds. hand towels
- 24 " tea towels
- 6 pkts. needles, etc.
- 8 spools thread, white
- 8 " black
- 10 prs. knitting needles
- 3 bundles fret saw wood
- 6 dozen " blades
- 6 paring knives
- 1 butcher knife
- 36 dinner knives
- 36 forks
- 24 soup spoons
- 24 " bowls
- 3 wash basins
- 2 brooms
- 36 clothes hooks

It is noted that the teacher requests 12 pounds wool and 25 yards cotton print. You may purchase a reasonable quantity of sewing materials and wool for the purpose of teaching plain sewing and knitting to the pupils, but the expenditure should be kept to a minimum.

Thirty-six tooth brushes will be sent from the Department.

The other articles on the requisition considered necessary are being ordered from the Government Stationery Office.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. P. Booth,
Indian Agent,
Muscow, Snake.

Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your voucher No. 286 amounting to $10.00 covering the cost of supplies purchased for midday meal purposes at the Assiniboine School. The account is being paid but I cannot understand why you have submitted this account in view of the contents of official letter of May 15, 1941, to which no reply has yet been received.

No further accounts for purchase of midday meal supplies will be paid until you reply to the letter mentioned above and a decision has been made regarding the amount, if any, which should be allowed for midday meal purposes at the Assiniboine School.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Booth,
Indian Agent,
Moose Jaw, Sask.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter #102-1-5 dated May 13, 1941, I wish to submit the following report:

The Day School on the Assiniboine Reserve is possibly one of the outstanding Day schools in the Province, both as regards to the work accomplished and to the average attendance, which is very high considering the distance some of the pupils have to travel to school.

The Indians on the reserve are very poor as they have had, until this year, nine complete crop failures. This condition has made it very difficult for the parents of the pupils to provide a satisfactory lunch.

There is no doubt that the lunch provided at the school is very beneficial to the health of the children and if the Department grant us the usual $10.00 per month, the cost per lunch for each child is approximately 1½ cents.

I would be very pleased to receive the authority as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Booth
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa,
December 25, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant with reference to a midday meal at the Assiniboine Day School. It has been decided to allow an amount of $10.00 a month for the period November 1, 1941, to March 31, 1942. The above amount must not be exceeded.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Booth,
Indian Agent,
Moose Jaw, Sask.

July 17th 1947.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re alterations Assiniboine Day School

With reference to the alterations necessary before we can operate two separate school rooms it will be necessary to alter the building we are now using as a ration house into a school room, renovate the building that was the Agency office into a teacherage and rebuild an implement shed into a ration house.

The building that we propose to make into a school-room is 26' x 26'. It will be necessary to take out all partitions and stairway, change entrance, build cloak-rooms 14' x 14', build 8 new windows in east wall, new tin roof 10 X 10, repair all plaster, complete paint job, new coal bin in basement, new cupboard, benches and table for 30 pupils, and basement lights.

It will also be necessary to build three outdoor toilets, the two for the school children will have to have a 30 ft fence erected between them.

Mr Erickson tender for this work is $2375.00

The building that we propose to use for a teacherage will necessitate some alterations and painting, the proposed work and tender is submitted, I may say that the building is in first class shape and will be ideal for such purposes, there also is a furnace in the basement which could be put in good working order for approximately $25.00.

We have a large implement shed 60 x 26 that is not used and this could be taken down and the most of the material used to build a rat-proof ration house. Mr Erickson has submitted a plan and tender for this work, quoting labor only, I do not consider that the extra material needed to complete the ration house would be over $200.00.
I am enclosing all plans and tenders from Mr Erickson and also to inform you that Mr Erickson is willing to provide labor only for all this work, the Department providing all material, at the following wages.

Foreman: $1.20 per hr
Carpenters @ 1.00 per hr.
Laborers @ 60c per hr.

We certainly would have a very fine school unit if this work was completed and would be able to have accommodation for 60 pupils.

I know that I am rather late asking for this work but I have been unable to get quotations from other firms and carpenters as everyone has more work ahead of them that they can do this year. Mr Erickson will commence work immediately so as to have the buildings ready for September 1st if he is awarded the contract.

Frank Booth,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Assiniboine Indian Day School

The growth in school population on the Assiniboine Indian Reserve is such that we will have to open an additional classroom this September. It is recommended by Mr. Ostendorf and the Indian Agent that we carry out the following alterations:

(a) Renovate the former agency office as a teachers' room.

(b) Alter the present ration house for use as an additional schoolroom.

(c) Rebuild the implement shed into a ration house.

After considerable delay we have finally located a contractor willing to do the above alterations. He is Mr. H. L. Erickson, of Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask. You will find attached the three tenders which Mr. Erickson has submitted for the work required to open this extra classroom. The total cost is $3,597.00. You will note that Mr. Erickson will provide labour, paint and materials for all alterations with the exception of the store-room, which will involve labour only. Most of the lumber for the store-room will be provided by tearing down the implement shed. We may have to provide a small quantity of lumber, cement and paint to complete this latter job.

EX'D. A.

October 7, 1946.

I have received your letter of October 4th in reply to mine of the 22nd in connection with the rebuilding of an implement shed on the Assiniboine Reserve into a ration or store house.

You did not return to me the account of Montmartre Co-operative Assoc. which was sent to you with letter of the 22nd.

I may say that the reason the account was returned was that the voucher (No. 477) was directed for payment to the Agencies Division, who had no knowledge of the work, and on account of the wording that the work was to provide a ration or storehouse no one in the Agencies Division realized that the matter was one which should have been referred to the Schools Branch.

Upon receipt of your letter of the 4th, however, the Agencies Division made a search for the Purchase Order referred to in your letter (No. 22044), and could not find it. However, Purchase Order 22040 was finally located and the School file drawn, when it was discovered that the matter should have gone in the first instance to the Indian Education Service.

I give you this information to show you how much trouble can be caused by a voucher not being completely worded. When sending in the voucher in this instance please state on it that the implement shed being remodelled is for the use of the School, being part of the group of buildings at the Assiniboine Agency required for school purposes.

M.W. Director.

INDUSTRIAL WORKERS GET BOOST

Four Unions Conclude Agreements

REGINA—Negotiations for wage increases have been completed with four groups of Saskatchewan government employees. Wage increases and pay boosts made in all cases, it was announced jointly recently by D. H. F. Black, deputy industrial executive, and C. G. Palmer, regional director of the Canadian Congress of Labor, parent body of all four unions.

The increase affects approximately 270 employees at the Government and Public Works Department, the Moose Jaw tannery at Regina of Saskatchewan Leather Products, the Moose Jaw woolen mill of Dominion Wool Products, the brick plant at Estevan of Clay Products, and the Government Insurance Office at Regina.

Increase in pay of five cents per hour "across the board" was granted the employees of the Moose Jaw Dominion Workers Local 32, representing employees of the sheep shearing and tannery, under the "last end" clause of their contract of the union. The new agreement, which took effect immediately upon its negotiation, makes the pay boost retroactive to August 1. The agreement concerns wages only and does not constitute a gaining agreement with the union does not expire until December 7.

Another agreement calling for five cents per hour increase, retroactive to June 1, was reached with the Dominion Woolen Mill employees represented by Dominion Workers of America Local 759, representing woolen mill employees.

Workers of the Saskatchewan Clay Products Workers Union Local No. 3 and the Saskatchewan Insurance Employees' Union had a new collective bargaining agreement to replace those which had expired on July 1. The agreement included changes in conditions were involved, as well as wage increases. Pay boosts in the case of the insurance office were retroactive August 15, while in the case of the Insurance Office they were retroactive to July 1.

"All negotiations with industrial employees have been completed except those with employees of the Saskatchewan Power Commission," Mr. Palmer said.

Commenting on the new agreements, Mr. Palmer said they had resulted in very satisfactory feeling among employees.

Fodder Still Serious In Areas, But Self-Help Program Assists

REGINA—While still serious in some northern areas, the feed and fodder shortage in Saskatchewan had eased considerably during the past few weeks, Agriculture Minister I. C. Nollet said recently. He added that improvement has resulted through the efforts of farmers engaging in the self-help program instituted by the department of agriculture.

While the feed and fodder deficiency in some districts will "still serious," the department stood a better chance of meeting the anticipated demands for fodder which may arise after November 1, he said. The minister urged farmers to make every effort to salvage all available feed in drought areas in order to more nearly meet the department's requirements.

Up-to-date lists of locations where hay and other fodder can be obtained on a basis by anyone willing to harvest it, are maintained by the agricultural extension division of the department. It is also available for purchase, Mr. Nollet pointed out. The cheapest hay, except that which he reserves for seed, will be that put up or moved under the department's fodder policy, thus providing the farmer with freight assistance until November 1, 1947, together with transportation costs of buying hay.

In the case of farmers who make hay for their own purposes, hay from available sources of supply, in-ward freight assistance in the amount of $2 per ton will be given. The suggestion that the government undertake full responsibility for the program and do the job alone is not a feasible program, but to do so, Mr. Nollet said, "would mean that only a limited amount of fodder would be available and supplies..."
LOCAL RADIO MAKES GOOD

ONE OF THE most important new aids to education is radio, and school radio broadcasts have developed to such an extent that the Saskatchewan Broadcasting Corporation and the various provincial education departments co-operate in producing programs for each of the five school days.

Dramatic productions bring to life history, literature, science and many other school subjects in a manner that holds children's interest so that learning becomes both easy and entertaining. Just how valuable these broadcasts can be is illustrated by the fact that one Saskatchewan radio station has received series of letters from during its evening program and received an enthusiastic response from its adult listeners.

But it was discovered in Saskatchewan, as it has been found in other parts of Canada and in the United States, that whereas programs which were recorded in the studio in good shape were not getting into the class rooms satisfactorily. After complaints had been received from Saskatchewan teachers James Kent, supervisor of the School Broadcasts Branch of the Department of Education, set out to investigate.

Reception Not Good

From first hand investigation Mr. Kent found a situation here similar to what had been found in other places. Radio receiving sets in use were simply not suitable for class room use. There were old sets, purchased to fit the budget of the local district, but even the newer sets were not satisfactory in school use, for which they were designed. Volume control, "muffled" sound effects were indistinct and music reproduction was inferior. In addition, many sets did not have enough power to enable children to tune without strain. If more power was used distortion became so bad as to ruin the program completely.

It was evident that what was needed was a radio receiving set which was built for class room use, instead of home use, and would perform satisfactorily under school conditions. Manufacturers in Canada were consulted, but all except one were not interested in producing a special type of receiver for school use. One manufacturer would agree to make a special set but only under conditions which were prohibitive.

Problem Could Be Solved

That was the state of the problem when it came to the attention of G. L. Powell who was in charge of maintenance of Saskatchewan Film Board movie projector equipment. Mr. Powell was an electrical engineer whose technical developments of radio from almost its earliest days. Years ago he had been one of that happy group of amateurs who had constructed their own receiving sets when radio was still a novelty and not the commonplace thing it is today.

Mr. Powell felt there was a way to solve the school radio problem, and he set out to find a solution. Initially the problem was a simple one. You had to produce a radio set that would give fine reproduction of the full range of audio tones at high volume from programs broadcast from nearby stations during the daytime.

Setting about to do this, Mr. Powell drew on his broad grasp of the techniques of radio. Ordinary hearing radios are fine for the purpose for which they are designed. In which tone necessarily sacrificed for great selectivity and static suppression, to which the school receiver was not required. Mr. Powell's problem was to design a radio having the characteristics wanted for school use, instead of those needed in home radios.

The first experimental set was finished in December, 1945. After tests and adjustments, the new receiver demonstrated that it was the answer to the school receiver problem. It did the work for which it was designed even better than had been hoped. Pleasantful realistic tone was matched by phenomenal power, which enabled the set to operate the same type of speakers required by set-oil receivers.

As Mr. Powell explains, he had worked out principles and invented something new and revolutionary. He had merely applied known principles to the making of a set capable of fulfilling a scientific purpose. By sacrificing selectivity, which is not needed in a school radio, and by providing for adequate power output, he had produced a machine which filled the bill perfectly. Addition of a phonograph pickup and turntable was made to allow teachers to use records for music instruction.

Production Started

By September, 1946, Department of Education officials had been convinced of the advantages of the new machine and the School Broadcasts Branch was given permission to produce them in quantity for Saskatchewan schools.

Since then till the end of August thirty-five 125-watt tube and electric radio-phones had been produced and delivered. During that time 150 orders were received from schools, and more are coming in every day.

The project has grown in size so that there is now a special division in the Department of Education, the Radio Production Branch, to make the radios. Mr. Powell is in charge and he has two young Saskatchewan veterans holding him, Roy Smith and Lawrence Babin. Mr. Smith, who comes from Rocanville, was a radio mechanic in the Air Force during the war. Mr. Babin, a Delisle, who was also in the Air Force, took a year's course in radio at the Moose Jaw vocational training school before joining the new branch.

Saskatchewan Made

The radios are an entirely Saskatchewan product, except, of course, for the various parts which are made by radio manufacturers, and these are purchased through Saskatchewan dealers.

Cabinets, for instance, are made by local cabinet makers in Saskatchewan at Regina, Qu'Appelle and Beechy. The steel chassis were first made by a local manufacturer, but when he was unable to obtain new sheet metal, and now they are made by a sheet metal fabricator in Regina.

The cabinets are another feature of the school radios which are specially designed for this use. Not made for display purposes, so much as for utility, they are nevertheless quite attractive. 1947 Seasons and Bag Limits For Game Birds Announced

REGINA.—Official 1947 migratory bird seasons and bag limits were announced recently by E. L. Paynter, game commissioner, as follows:

Season for ducks, geese, coots and Wilson's snipe in that portion of the province north of south line from boundary of township 50 is set at September 22 to October 31. North of township 50 and south of township 60 season for these birds opens September 15 and closes October 31. North of township 60 the season on all four species will run from September 8 to October 31.

A closed season is in effect on elder and wood ducks, swans, cranes, and all migratory non-game and insectivorous birds.

Bag limits are set as follows: daily—seven ducks, five geese, 10 coots, and five snipe; season limit—56 ducks, 20 geese, 50 coots and 25 snipe; possession limit—14 ducks, 10 geese, 36 coots and five snipe. Possession of migratory birds killed during the open season is allowed in Saskatchewan until March 31.

The use of any weapon other than a shotgun or bow and arrow is prohibited.

Name Northern Lake After Jerrold Smith

REGINA.—Large, newly-named Jerrold Lake, in the rocky pine belt of the northern Saskatchewan, about 20 miles west of Cree Lake, will honor the memory of F/O Jerrold Smith, who died in action while engaged on air operations in August, 1943, and presumed dead in April, 1943. F/O Jerrold Smith's parents live at 3982 18th avenue, Regina.

Enlisting with the air force in 1940, F/O Smith was commissioned and went overseas in 1941. He took operational training as a fighter pilot in northern Ireland, was posted to the Royal Air Force there in 1942, and there gained for himself the reputation of being an efficient combat pilot during the bitterest of the German attacks.

The name Jerrold Lake has been approved by the National Geographic Board, and the necessary documents of the action will be filed in the provincial archives as part of the province's history, according to Mr. Paynter.
Dantow Named Health Officer

REGINA — Dr. Matthew Dantow, B.Sc., M.B., Ch.B., D.P.H., has been appointed medical health officer of the North Eastern Health Region No. 19, succeeding to a similar appointment by Deputy Health Minister Dr. C. F. W. Hames.

Since November, 1946, the medical officer of the newly formed region has worked with the Provincial Services Plan and the Regional Health Service Division of the Saskatchewan Department of Public Health.

Born in New York City in 1909, Dr. Dantow received his bachelor of arts degree from the University of New York in 1930, and his bachelor of surgery and medical degree from the University of Glasgow in 1936. The following year he took a three-month course in tropical medicine at the University of London. In 1946 he received a diploma in public health from the University of Toronto.

In 1936 and 1937 Dr. Dantow was house surgeon in the Royal Infirmary at Doncaster, England. From 1938 to 1944 he engaged in private practice in the United Kingdom, including Scotland, serving also as part-time medical health officer. He was medical health officer of the town of John's, Newfoundland, from 1944 to 1946.

Corman Asks for Vigorous Action Against Price-Fixing Combines

REGINA — A statement from the Saskatchewan government requesting the Dominion government to take more vigorous action against monopolies and cartels was issued by Acting Premier J. L. Corman following the announcement of Justice Minister J. L. Isley that a combine in restraint of price competition existed in the dental supply industry.

"The people of Saskatchewan are convinced that price-fixing combines exist in many other industries and that action by the federal authorities is long overdue," Mr. Corman said. "With government price controls practically gone the public is entitled to protection against exorbitant prices fixed and maintained by monopolies and cartels."

Mr. Corman pointed out that criminal information has recently been filed against a combine in the province alleging a conspiracy to fix automobile tire prices. And he added that the war crimes act of Great Britain documents had been introduced linking 53 United States and seven Canadian firms with former German combines.

"The people of this province are demanding that the Canadian counterparts of those German big shots be investigated from top to bottom and where they failings end police control is established that they be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law," the attorney-general added.

Mr. Corman said the Saskatchewan government considers that the absence of price control meant that control merely passed to large corporations engaged in monopolistic practices, and he added that failure to take action against all combines, monopolies and cartels would confirm this view.

Car Crashes Cut

REGINA — Saskatchewan citizens killed or injured in motor vehicle accidents during the peak summer driving period last year were less in number than for the corresponding period in 1947, according to the Saskatchewan Government Insurance office. There were 21 people killed and 587 injured in the first five months of the present license year, and in the same period in 1947 there were lost three lives and 706 were injured.

A total of 1,100 claims for collision damage were made up to the end of August, an indication that motorists were not involved in accidents where collision damage exceeded $100 in the case of non-registered vehicles under the provision of the A.A.A. for other vehicles.

Three Clinics Operating To Treat Polio Patients

REGINA — With a total of more than 160 recorded cases of poliomyelitis in Saskatchewan up to the early part of September, the expansion of clinic facilities to cope with the increased incidence of the disease was outlined recently by Dr. H. M. Doyle, director of the Division of Communicable Diseases in the Department of Health.

Two new clinics, Regina and Moose Jaw, have opened to provide additional facilities since the original clinic at St. Paul's Hospital in Saskatoon, which opened in July, 1943, was not sufficient to handle the epidemic.

A 50-bed clinic was opened at the Regina general hospital with the cooperation of local health authorities; the staff of the hospital included physicians. The Department of Health provided special equipment while both city and county health departments provided extra nurses. The Department also provides a nurse specifically assigned to each clinic for re-education, while contracts were made with orthopedic surgeons to supervise physical treatment to patients.

A similar new summer clinic was also set up in Moose Jaw. In all three cases the hospitalization and nursing services were provided free of charge, while hospital doctors' fees were not paid. Practically all of the 160 recorded cases in the province have been treated at the clinics.

The Department of Health feels that treatment of polio, which in cases of paralysis patients may run into months or years although many cases are cured in a short time, will prove an economic catastrophe to most families, and therefore it is our policy to provide so-called "treatment" free," said Dr. Doyle.

The clinic in Saskatoon, which has been in operation since 1943, was designed to reduce disability and prevent the appearance of new deformities. Of the 100 cases treated during the year, the clinic provided treatment for an indefinite time using a modified type of the Jonas technique.

From January, 1944, to March this year 77 cases were treated. Of this number 74, including three cases of long standing, 50 were discharged free of handicap, 14 were discharged with some handicap, and there was one death.

Teacher Shortage Still Great, But Increased Training Helps

REGINA — The present shortage of teachers in Saskatchewan will result in some rural schools remaining closed temporarily, Education Minister Woodrow Lloyd said today.

About 1,300 teachers of an approximate total of 4,500 who had taught school in 1946, gave up their teaching jobs at the end of the school year. The Ministry of Education's addition of a total of 900 new teachers, but there is a pressing need for at least 500 more teachers in the province.

While the present situation was serious, said Mr. Lloyd, he felt that the future looked far more encouraging, in that registration at the college of education at Saskatoon had reached 1,500 and was expected to be 560 by the time classes began. The minister pointed out that this number was an increase on record for teachers taking advanced training. They would eventually be absorbed into the educational stream to provide higher teaching standards.

Conforming to the policy of previous years, the Ministry of Education is releasing a number of normal school students at the end of October to fill the gaps in teacher ranks. This means that some of the students sent out as temporary teachers would have only about six weeks teaching experience.

Additionally 200 more students had enrolled for normal school training this year than in 1946, the aggregate to reach a total of 500 with the possibility of an additional 100 students registered next fall, Mr. Lloyd said that school boards were enlisting the aid of former school teachers to help meet the present educational emergency. These teachers would be employed for the whole or part of the school year until the situation eased.

Memorandum:

MR. PERLAN,

Assiniboine Indian Day School.

On Mr. Hoey's recommendation of August 5th, 1947, the contract was awarded to Mr. H.L. Erichson of Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan. His recommendation reads, "You will find attached the three tenders which Mr. Erichson has submitted for the work required to open this extra classroom. The total cost is $3,597.00. You will note that Mr. Erichson will provide labour, paint and materials for all alterations with the exception of the store-room, which will involve labour only. Most of the lumber for the store-room will be provided by tearing down the implement shed. We may have to provide a small quantity of lumber, cement and paint to complete this latter job".

It appears that this expenditure of $361.42 for Montmartre Co-op Assn, is for this additional material that is required to build the store-room from the torn down implement shed. This account should not be charged to Purchase Order 22040 as indicated by the Agent. Mr. F. Booth in his letter of July 17, 1947, indicated that this extra material would cost not more than $200.00.

The last paragraph on the Purchase Order 22040 reads as follows: "The above price ($3,597.00) includes labour, paint, and materials for all alterations with the exception of the store-room which would involve labour only".
The following sums have been paid to Mr. Erichson in connection with this work:

Oct. 22 V.R. 495 Labour & Material $800.36
Oct. 24 V.R. 496 Trucking of Lumber 22.00
Nov. 3 V.R. 509 To complete job on School room 2432.87

Re: Purchase Order 22040

The above covered the alterations and repairs to the buildings at the Assiniboine Agency in order to provide a second class room for the Assiniboine Day School. If you will review that purchase order you will note that it was divided into three sections, (a), (b) and (c).

You submitted voucher 495 for $800.36. Of this amount $525.00 was shown in item (c) of the purchase order and we presumed the amount over and above $525.00 was some of the material approved by section (b) and consequently paid the whole voucher at a total amount of $800.36.

You subsequently submitted voucher 509 for $2,432.87. The purchase order only authorized $2,375.00 but we arranged to pay the additional amount requested. You also submitted voucher 496 for trucking lumber; this amounted to $22.00.

The total amount already paid is as follows:

- Voucher 509: $2,432.87

the balance left in this purchase order is, therefore only $341.77 ($3,597.00 - $3,255.23).

Deputy Minister,
Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

We, the undersigned, Members of the Assiniboine Reserve and parents of children who are attending the two-room Day School on our Reserve humbly pray that a school van with a capable driver be provided at least for the cold winter months commencing from the 1st of October to the 31st of March, to enable the pupils, who live from three to six miles away from school to maintain regular attendance.

Heretofore some of us had to send our children to the Residential Schools but this breaks up the family ties, whilst others had to carry on with the unequal fight against the elements of blizzards and bitter cold during the winter months to avail themselves of the facilities provided by the Indian Department on our reserve.

However, now that the Department has completed the two room Day School on our Reserve we have every reason to believe that the "Great White Father" will give favourable consideration to our plea.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of the 19th inst regarding the fireman wages at the Assiniboine Day School, I wish to report as follows.

On a recent visit of myself and Mr Ostrander to the Assiniboine reserve the question of caring for the two school furnaces came up and it was found that the Indian women did not give the care that was necessary to obtain sufficient heat, also they were not able to keep the fire baskets in the furnaces sufficiently clean and therefore new grates would be needed frequently, so it was decided to hire a man as fireman for both schools, also it was decided that $15.00 per month would be a fair wage. Edwin Ryder was placed in charge of the furnaces but I should have immediately asked you for the authority to hire a fireman.

As it is necessary to have this man hired to care for the furnaces during the winter months, kindly give the authority.

Frank Booth,
Superintendent.
January 30th, 1950.

Ottawa, March 21, 1912.

Sir,

Referring to your report on the Assiniboine Day School and the matter of the enlargement of the basement and improvements to the cabin erected for the use of the Indians who bring their children to school in order that it may be made fit for a teacher's residence I have to ask you to be good enough to submit an estimate of the cost of this work, at the same time stating how you would propose to have it done. I may say that both of these suggested improvements meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.
Extract from Mr. Inspector Graham's report on the Assiniboine Day School, dated February 28, 1912.

Last year I received your permission to enlarge the basement of this school but owing to a very busy fall and the unfortunate conditions at this Agency, I was unable to get the work done. The want of a large basement is much felt and I hope to get the work done this spring. In this connection I would ask if it will be necessary to have a renewal of your authority.

There is another matter that I would like to bring before you for your favorable consideration. When the school was built a small shell of a cabin was erected for the use of the Indians who might bring their children to school. It was found that this building was not used very much in view of the fact that the children were driven to and from school by an Indian hired for the purpose. Miss Lawrence, late last fall, converted this into a living house and she resided there ever since. She asks that the Department spend $150 to $200 in lining this cabin and adding a small lean-to kitchen for her cook stove, etc. I would strongly advise that this be done. She is doing excellent work and deserves encouragement. Might I at the same time ask permission to buy a foot-ball for the use of the pupils. Miss Lawrence has asked for this several times.
I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No.334701/5, dated the 1st instant.

In reply I will say that the work at Assiniboine school and the teacher's shack could be done without engaging skilled labor. I have a fair knowledge of cement and concrete work myself. I could supervise the carpenter work, which can be done by some of our Indian boys.

Kindly specify what has to be done with the school and the teacher's shack. The farm instructor and myself will attend to this matter.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 17, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to know that you will undertake the supervision of the repairs and changes at the Assiniboine School. Mr. Inspector Graham has been written to with reference to the details of the work to be done and as soon as this information is received you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. E. Donnelly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sintaluta, Sask.
I beg to inform you that I visited the Assiniboine Agency on Tuesday last and in accordance with your instructions submit herewith particulars as to the work that should be done in connection with the Day School and teacher's residence at that point.

Day School

There are about three hundred and fifty yards of earth to be excavated from underneath the building. This will give a full sized basement of 32x26. It will be necessary to build a concrete wall 32 feet long on the East side of the basement and another wall 20 feet long on the north side. The floor of the new basement will have to be cemented and three extra windows put in.

The Teacher was very anxious to have a galvanized iron cistern put in the basement so that she could use the soft water from the roof. I would advise that her request be granted as they use a great deal of water at this institution.

Teacher's residence.

The little cabin that the teacher is now using is only a mere shell. The idea is to line this building with building paper and V joint ceiling and it can then be used as a kitchen. An addition 18' X 14' X 8' should then be added.

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
be built to it. This could be made very comfortable if built on the following lines: - 2x4 studdings set at 20" centres, lined inside and out with ship lap, covered with paper and siding on the outside and paper and V joint on the inside. The most of the work in connection with this little house and the basement of the school can be done by the Agent's staff and Indians at a cost of about $600.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith memorandum of the repairs and improvements in connection with the Assiniboine School submitted by Mr. Inspector Graham. The Department desires to have this work done by day labour under your supervision and you may commence work on the residence at once. The work in connection with the school-room may be left until the school closes at the end of next month. Indian labour should be used as much as possible and the rate of wages allowed should be fair. I am enclosing herewith pay sheets, which you will be good enough to submit to the Department weekly. Payment will be made for the material upon the presentation of vouchers. I am sending you, under separate cover, an accountable cheque for $100.00 for the payment of wages. The Department trusts that you will have this work carried out expeditiously and at a reasonable expense.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Attached requisition for furnace for Teacherage - Assiniboine Reserve.

Purchase order 35033 has been issued for a new furnace for the Assiniboine School, but Indian Superintendent Kerley now advises that a furnace is also required for the teachers' residence on this reserve.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of

No.

Concerning Farming Instructor J.C. Macleod of the Big River Reserve, I have the honor to report that the relations between him and the Indians under him have been strained from the beginning of his work there. Umbrage was first taken by them at his exclusion of them from his dwelling. His predecessor had allowed them the freedom of the house and invited them to the table whenever their visits coincided with the meal time. The change was very marked and antagonized them.

Mr. Macleod has a very forceful and masterful manner in directing their work which they resent, and the unpleasantness between them has steadily increased, until a recent occasion when he lost his temper, and struck the orphaned boy Daniel Metmaker son of the late Hector (Mynneekikwonape H.M.No.14). This furnished a desired opportunity to the Indians and those outsiders whom he had antagonized; proceedings have been threatened and so much outside out of it that his influence over these Indians has been lost. He resigned this fact and after first tendering his resignation has replaced it with a request for a transfer to some other reserve where his wife could also be employed in teaching. I recognize that Mr. Macleod has been most earnest in the discharge of his duties, and that his failure has been chiefly due to over zeal and an uncontrollable temper. I also recognize the excellent qualities of his wife; the kindly sympathy with which she attracted the Indians' children, while maintaining a strict firm discipline over them. She will be missed from the Big River School, and I very much regret that her husband's hasty temper should apparently render impossible her continuance in the work.

With the hope that the Department may know of a suitable exchange such as asked for by Mr. Macleod which will also continue Mrs. Macleod's services to the Department,

I have the honor to remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 3rd inst., and in reply I beg to say that the Department approves of your action in placing Mrs. McLeod in charge of the Big River school.

The Department recognizes how difficult it is to secure teachers with proper qualifications for schools on outlying reserves. Much good work may be done, however, by Mrs. McLeod, if she is interested in Indian work. The enrolment at this school is not as large as it should be, and if, after a fair trial, Mrs. McLeod is able to show an improvement in this and other respects, the Department will be pleased to continue her services.

The Department does not wish Mrs. McLeod to confine her efforts to the school work alone, but would like her to pay attention to the betterment of the home life of the Indians on the reserve in respect to cleanliness, neatness, ventilation, cooking, etc., working in conjunction with her husband, whose aim should be to raise the standard of husbandry among these Indians.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, informing me that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan, has made a request that the Indian day School on the Big River Reserve, Carlton Agency, be reopened and pointed out that both the school house and Teachers residence are in a shocking condition.

This is quite true, the school and residence are in a shocking condition. The buildings are old log structures and I doubt if they can be made habitable. The school has been nothing more or less than absolute failure, during the last two years that it was open.

The Indians in this Reserve are hunters and are away a great deal of the time, and naturally this makes it hard to keep up a school. The Indians take little or no interest in education and although there has been a school on this Reserve for years, I doubt if you can find a child on the reserve that shows any appearance of ever having attended it.

In view of these conditions, I cannot advise the re-opening of this school, infact it would be a mistake to do so.

But how to find educational facilities for these children and the children of other Reserves, that are under the auspices of the Anglican church is a question that will have to receive the serious consideration of the Department, as the day schools in this District are not a success. The sooner we can provide an up-to-date residential school that will take care of all the Anglican children on the north, the better it will be for the Indians and the Department.

Extract from Report of Inspector Murison on the Big River Indian Day School.

I visited this school on January 29th, it is situated on the Big River Reserve about forty miles north of the Agency. This school was re-opened in September 1924 with Mr. R.B. Settee in charge as teacher. Mr. Settee had been teacher at the Montreal Lake Day School for a number of years, but I am informed did not make a success of that school. It is my opinion that he does not possess the personality required to make a success as a school teacher. While he is very respectable he does not possess the force of character which is necessary to command attendance at an Indian Day School.

The old class room has been repaired and I found it very clean and nicely decorated with spruce branches. The Church Authorities have not made provisions for proper housing accommodation for this man, and he is living in the old farm house which is in a very poor state of repair.

There are twenty-six pupils enrolled, twelve boys and fourteen girls. They range in age from six to sixteen years. The average attendance for the past month is shown on the register as 12.61. The children have to come from two to four miles, and I am told that many cannot come during the cold weather on account of poor clothing. The members of this Band largely subsist by hunting and take their children along with them when following this pursuit. It would be a difficult matter to operate a Day School successfully under those conditions. In my opinion I think it would be advisable that an increased effort be made to have these children attend the Boarding Schools. A start has been made already in this direction, but I think a more determined effort should be made to have these children properly cared for.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the five Day Schools in the Carlton Agency, which were inspected by Mr. Murison during the latter part of November and the early part of December.

The Big River Day School has never been considered satisfactory. The attendance is irregular and the building is poor. I cannot see that any improvement has taken place since the last inspection. In forwarding a report on this school on February 14th, last, I stated that I was in doubt as to whether it would be advisable to build a new school or not, and I am still of this opinion. The children in this northern part of the country will, sooner or later, have to be brought to a Boarding School, as none of the Day Schools at this point are doing what I consider to be good work.

The average attendance at the Sturgeon Lake Day School is not bad, considering the conditions under which the Indians are living. This is undoubtedly the best school of the lot. You will note that the teacher has no desk. It might be a good idea to send one from Eaton's, as it would cost very little. There is nothing in the Estimates to provide for a floor for the teacher's residence. This, however, would not cost more than $25.00. The heating stove in the building should be replaced without delay. This will cost about $35.00.

You will note that the Sandy Lake Day School is a log building sheeted on the outside and wainscoted inside with V-joint. The Inspector says it should be re-kalsomined and painted inside, and I may say that there is an amount in the Estimates for this purpose. You will note that there is indifference here on the part of the Indians about sending their children to school.

With reference to the Wahpaton Sioux Day School, I may say that, in my opinion, it has never amounted to anything and never will.

I visited this school on February 19th and found 5 pupils in attendance out of an enrollment of 16. I noted from the register that 7 of these pupils attended very regularly, practically 100%, the balance of the pupils attending very intermittently. Practically all the children come from homes within a radius of 3 miles of the school. The 5 pupils in attendance were all in Grade 1. I asked them questions in English, but they did not appear to understand me. They did understand Cree and would answer me in that language. In so far as the academic work is concerned at this school, I consider it very unsatisfactory.

Fifteen of the pupils are classed in Grade 1 and 1 in Grade 2.

When on the Reserve the Indians complained to me that their children were not learning anything and they charged that the teacher was not giving the time and attention to work in the classroom that he should. Mr. Eastwood holds a First Class Permanent certificate. His academic standing is good. However after seeing the school and the teacher, I am of the opinion that he is out of his element in an Indian day school. The Indians apparently have no confidence in him and I question if he has the personality to inspire the necessary confidence to enlist the cooperation of the Indian parents. I am now quite in accord with Mr. Davis in that there should be a change of teachers at this point, if we are to expect even a measure of success in connection with the work of the school.

I found the school building neat and tidy, as well as the teacher's cottage and premises. I am sure the children are not below average in intelligence and they are capable of being taught, but it is a question of obtaining a teacher who can impress his personality on the Indian parents and make the school work attractive to the Indian pupils. The Chief and Councillors were sufficiently interested in this question to make a special trip of nearly 40 miles to the Agency to see me for the purpose of having another talk and put in a further appeal to have this teacher transferred and a new one appointed. With that feeling towards a teacher existing, it will be impossible to look forward to much success.

NUMBER WORK OR ARITHMETIC: In this line of activity pupils displayed little more than the ability to count as far as "ten". Pronunciation was good with the exception of those sounds with which children of this race experience special difficulty,- "f", "v", "l", and "th". They evidently have some idea of what they are reading, but it is very difficult to induce them to make any attempt to express this idea in their own words.

Dear Sir:

In amplification of question re Interest of Parents in children's Education, I beg to state that with a band existing by trapping and hunting, there is not that keenness for education that is seen in other bands. Especially at this time of the year, the whole band seems to go off after muskrats, only one or two leaving their wives and children. All those living within 3 miles attend whenever they are on the reserve.

One man always sends notice when he is going away, and sends his children as soon as he returns. Another has built a house one-half mile from school, so as to give his children a chance, but has gone back to the North end of reserve for trapping. There are one or two more who need no urging to send their children but in many cases I have to try to get them by talking to the parents. The two councillors help, but the chief is not very keen. June 4th., - 1937.

Dear Sir:

Reference Your No.107-3-1 of May 15th.
Big River School.

In reply to this letter I shall attempt to give my ideas and reason for the conclusion at which I have arrived.

In a survey of the Reserves on which we have day schools, we find certain reserves where agriculture predominates, others where hunting and trapping are the chief source of subsistence. On the farming Reserves there are farming instructors, on the others the only contact we have is through the occasional visits of the Agent, or through the School teacher.

In the appointment of teachers I think consideration should be given to each particular type of Reserve. For example, on an agriculture Reserve there is a farming instructor, the Indians are more advanced. On these Reserves a more intensive programme of education can be carried on, sewing, knitting and housekeeping should be stressed, and I think the teacher should be required to visit the homes, organize the women and give half a day a week instructing them in sewing, knitting, handicraft and

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
housekeeping work, using the school room for that purpose. The farming instructor should, during the winter, give half a day a week to instructing the boys in the use of the hammer, saw, etc. He could do this on the day the teacher had the women's class, and the girls could work with their mothers.

The carrying out of this policy would necessitate the employment of women teachers, or a married man whose wife would undertake to instruct the girls and women in sewing, etc.

On Reserves where hunting and trapping predominate I think a man teacher who would fill the dual position of Teacher and Overseer would be in the best interests. This man should, of course, be carefully selected and with the understanding that his wife would be required to instruct the girls in sewing, etc., and also organize the women for the same purpose.

The Indians on these Reserves are very backward. We cannot hope to make any great advance in either education or farming in this generation. Consequently a man and woman with the ability to impart knowledge and a propensity to social work, together with a fair education and a knowledge of gardening and farming should be selected for the position.

With a closer co-operation with the Church and a better understanding of what our aims and objects are, I do not think we should have any difficulty in securing satisfactory men and women for these positions.

Kinistino Reserve - We have had a farming instructor on this Reserve for some time but these Indians are very backward. They do not believe in education and do very little agricultural work. I may be wrong, but it is my opinion that a man and woman of the type mentioned will for the next few years do better work than a separate farming instructor and teacher and at less expense to the Department.

Big River Reserve - This is another place where in my opinion we should have a man as teacher and overseer. We have, however, in Miss. Merrett a splendid teacher and one whose services should not be lost to the Department. As there is no other school to which she could be transferred, I would recommend that no action be taken this year. This will give us time to give the matter
Further consideration, and if next Spring a change is considered advisable, the probabilities are that a transfer could be arranged.

I am in accord with the necessity for security of tenure and that the teacher should not be dismissed for not doing work they were informed came under the contract. At the same time I do not think that a teacher who takes no interest in anything outside his school, more particularly on Reserves where there is no other representative of the Department, is the type of person we want in the service.

It appears to me that there is not the cooperation between the different branches of the service that there should be. The Teacher, the Missionary, the Clerk, etc., seem to feel that theirs are separate units or machines, that their work is circumscribed by certain limits, and that the cooperation, assistance or advice of one Branch is not asked for, appreciated, or wanted by the other.

I believe if we could impress upon the minds of the members of each Branch, including the clergy, the fact that they are not separate units but that they are vital cogs of one machine, working for the advancement of the Indian, that the success of one depends upon the success of the other, that their cooperation, assistance and advice is not only welcome but vitally necessary, we would make much greater progress.

In conclusion I wish to say that I believe we have not paid enough attention to the Indian woman. The Indian woman has great influence on the destiny of the Indian, she makes or breaks him.

We spend a lot of money educating the girls in cleanliness, housekeeping, etc., yet when they marry we let them go into homes when they have nothing to work with, nothing in which they can take any pride or that will keep up their morale. I am satisfied the fault is greatly ours that so many of them fail and that $75.00 or $100.00 spent in supplying these young couples with household equipment would do more to advance them than $200.00 spent on horses, etc.

I trust I have not worried you with my ideas.

Yours very truly,

Thos. Robertson
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, June 11, 1937.

Dear Omer:

Re: Your letter of July 16, Big River Reserve.

With reference to the Big River School I might point out that our Schools both Residential and Day are run under the auspices of either Church. That Church nominates the Teachers, and so long as that School continues that Church has this privilege. The Big River School is under the auspices of the Church of England, consequently the Church of England has the right of nominating the Teacher. Any effort to have a Roman Catholic appointed to this School would simply stir up trouble, as any effort to have a Protestant appointed to a School under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church would. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Big River Indian Day School

I desire to acknowledge receipt of Mr. Pratt's memoranda of July 30 and August 5 enclosing correspondence from Dr. H. R. Fleming, M.P., Omer Demers, M.L.A., and Rev. G. E. Paquette, O.M.I., requesting that a Catholic teacher be employed at the above-mentioned school.

About thirty years ago the Anglican Church authorities brought to the Department's attention the necessity for having a day school on this Reserve. The Big River School was started at that time and ever since the Anglican Bishop of Saskatchewan has been allowed to nominate the teacher.

The statistics regarding the religion of the Indians of the Big River Band as supplied in Mr. Demers' letter are practically the same as shown in our official census of 1934. From this it is evident that the Catholics on the Big River Reserve greatly outnumber the Anglicans.

As our day school return forms do not require the teacher to state the religion of the pupils attending the school I am unable to advise you whether or not the information regarding the religion of the children of school age is correct.
I am under the impression that very few of the Catholic Indian children have been attending the day school but they have usually been enrolled at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. Owing to the general increase in school population the Duck Lake School apparently finds it impossible to accept as many children as formerly from the Big River Reserve. As a result the Catholic children of school age on the Big River Reserve are apparently attending the day school in larger numbers and, as the Catholics are in the majority on the Reserve, the Missionary, Rev. G.E. Paquette, O.M.I., considers that the teacher should be a Catholic.

It will be difficult to change the teacher for the academic year 1938-39 due to the fact that the school year opens within the next few weeks and the same teacher who was in charge of the school last year is, I understand, prepared to resume duties.

On the other hand the Catholic Indians have the right, under the Indian Act, to demand a school conducted under Catholic auspices, provided they have sufficient children to justify operation of a day school. From the information now available it would appear that this is the case. However, I am communicating with Inspector Robertson requesting him to obtain definite information regarding the religion of the children of school age on this Reserve in order that we can ascertain how many of them are Catholics and how many Anglicans.

I return the correspondence which was forwarded with the two memoranda mentioned above.

Acting Director.

Dear Miss Merritt:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 27th ultimo, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, a number of problems confronting you in the operation of your school.

I must express regret that the funds at our disposal did not permit us to proceed with the reconstruction of the kitchen at your school. However, if you are urgently in need of a stove, you should submit your request to the Indian agent and have him forward it to the Department. If this is done, an attempt will be made to purchase a stove at the earliest possible date.

The earlier part of your letter suggests that an attempt is being made to have a Roman Catholic school established on your reserve. If such is the case, this action is in no sense due to dissatisfaction with your work. It is my opinion that your work at the school has been uniformly good and uniformly satisfactory over a period of years. The Department has not the right, however, to send Roman Catholic children to a Protestant school or to a school conducted under Protestant auspices. Section 10 - subsection 2 - of the Indian Act reads:

"No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices".

I have been informed that this has been the law in Canada since -

Dear Sir,

Reverend Father G.E. Paquette, O.M.I., ministrant at Big River, Indian Reservation, in Saskatchewan, and who comes from my own city, calls the following facts to my attention and asks me to make them known to you. In his letter, he states:

"Since September, we have difficulty in getting certain children to attend school. They say that at the Anglican school they can stay away as much as they like and that the family allowance is granted to them just the same. The Department had set five days for absenteeism. If the children are absent over five days per month, they do not get the allowance. At the school here, the teacher is strict about this. Last fall, young Sam Lachance of the Anglican school spent almost two weeks in front of the Catholic school waiting for the pupils to go and play. The nuns have, like myself, seen young Lachance play truant. The allowance was granted for that month such as in the case of the pupils who attend school regularly. I would not have said a word if the councillor Thomas Whitefish whose children go to the Anglican school had not stated before three or four Indians at our school, "at the Anglican school the children are absent as often as they like and the allowance is granted regularly." That is a source of annoyance for us and it seems to me that the same law must apply to the children of other denominations as well as to the Catholic pupils.

Recently an Indian woman, Mrs. Benjamin Netmaker went to the Ste. Famille hospital at Prince Albert. After having been examined, the doctors stated that she took too great a quantity of Indian medicine and that her internal tissues are destroyed. That is what Dr. Tucker of Prince Albert said here to a family on the reserve, and he tried to find out who gave her the medicine. First, this woman got indian remedies from Frank
Netmaker and in addition, he bled her at the elbow. I have proofs concerning what I state. Then, Charlie Lachance also gave her medicine. When they have wheedled as much money as possible from the patient and when they see that there is no more hope, those two men call for a doctor and, if the latter is not successful, they accuse him of being inefficient, etc. I think that this is the good time to bring those two nitwits to their senses, particularly in this case; it is thought, according to the doctor's report, that the woman has blood poisoning. I would ask the Indian Department to get busy and to see that the two men get severe punishment. Then the whites who live near the reservation will stop to believe that the Indian Department is not doing its duty in this respect and that the Department appoints unqualified doctors to look after the Indians."

I believe that those facts certainly deserve your personal consideration and that of your department. Hoping to hear from you soon, I remain,

Yours truly,
Lionel Bertrand,
M.P. Terrebonne.

Dear Mr. Castleden:

I have for answer your letter of April 7 addressed to the Superintendent of Education. The information which you requested is as follows. On the Big River Reserve there are two day schools in operation. One of these is for the Roman Catholic children (the 1944 census shows 199 Catholics) and one for the Anglican children (the census shows 65 Indians for this denomination).

Both schools are located on the reserve about a mile and a half apart. They are identical in size and structure, but the classroom operated for the Roman Catholic children is crowded, and we are now investigating the possibilities of enlarging it. The teacher at the Anglican school is an Indian named Smith Atimoyoo who attended high school in Prince Albert and then attended Emmanuel College for a period of four years. There he received his Associate in Theology. He taught at the Shoal Lake Indian Day School from 1942 to 1947. He began teaching at the Big River C.E. Indian Day School in September, 1947.

The teacher at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School is Sister Marie Ladislas. She holds a First Class Teaching Certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan and has had three years of experience in private and provincial schools. She was appointed to this position on the 1st September, 1948, and replaced Sister Bernadette Marie who also had a First Class Teaching Certificate with some ten years of experience in provincial schools.

Our Educational Survey Officer spent a considerable part of last Spring in Saskatchewan, and as a result of his inspections, we are planning the building of a number
of day schools in that province. As you are aware, we have completed the schools at Meadow Lake, Nut Lake and Poorman. The new two-room school at Thunderchild is just now beginning construction.

We will shortly be advertising for tenders for other schools.

These schools are inspected by both the Provincial School Inspectors and by our own Indian Superintendents. The school inspectors naturally concentrate on classroom technique and teaching methods, whereas our superintendents check on the condition of the building, cleanliness of the children and school administration generally.

The Provincial School Inspectors visit these schools at least once a year, and our own superintendents visit them as often as possible, usually once a month.

I hope the above information provides you with the facts you are seeking.

Sincerely yours,

Director.

These schools are inspected by both the Provincial School Inspectors and our own Indian Superintendents. The School Inspectors naturally concentrate on classroom technique and teaching methods, whereas our Superintendents check on the condition of the building, cleanliness of the children and school administration generally. The Provincial School Inspectors visit these schools at least once a year, and our own Superintendents visit them as often as possible, usually once a month.

I hope the above information provides you with the facts you are seeking.

Yours sincerely,

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 26 concerning the Big River Indian Day Schools. It has been necessary to check carefully our records to provide you with the information requested.

The enrolment and average attendance at the Big River Roman Catholic School for the months 1 September, 1948, to 31 March, 1949, is as follows:

| Month       | Enrolment | Average |
|-------------|-----------|---------|
| 1948        |           |         |
| September   | 39        | 31.00   |
| October     | 40        | 35.98   |
| November    | 40        | 35.35   |
| December    | 39        | 33.62   |
| 1949        |           |         |
| January     | 35        | 31.21   |

|-------------|-----------|---------|
| September 1948 | 24        | 21.30   |
| October     | 24        | 22.40   |

| December    | 25        | 20.84   |

| February    | 25        | 21.55   |
| March       | 23        | 20.58   |
If we are able to complete our building program this year, I feel that educational facilities will be provided for most of the Indian children in Saskatchewan. As you are aware, the Residential Schools at Prince Albert are now providing for many of the children formerly served by the Lac La Barge Residential School. The Gordon's Residential School has been closed for major repairs and the provision of an adequate water supply. It will re-open in September, 1949. Even with one school being closed, the enrolment at our residential schools in Saskatchewan has increased by 46 this year over the number enrolled last year.

The Day School statistics are as follows:

| Year   | Number of Schools | Enrolment | Average |
|--------|-------------------|-----------|---------|
| 1947-48| 31                | 900       | 761     |
| 1948-49| 33                | 1009      | 829     |
| Increase| 2                 | 109       | 68      |

I feel that our school building program this year and next year will go a long way towards alleviating the present school shortage in Saskatchewan.

Yours sincerely,

CANADA
May 15th, 1926

Mr. Ross,
Superintendent of Indian Education,

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it is over a month ago since I sent my March Quarterly Return to Carlton Indian Office, and up to the present time I have not received anything. I write this to let you know that it would be a great help to me if I were to get any pay just at the end of each quarter. The men that supply us things we need such as provisions and gas etc., want their pay, and if I can't pay them on time or sooner they won't give us anything which makes it hard for me and for them. If it is the policy of the Department to keep me waiting for a month and a half after the end of each quarter you please let me know, and they see fit to them.

I have a pretty good school, and I am glad to say that the children have done very well so far. It is only during the hunting season that the attendance is down as the Indians go out to trap and take their children with them as they have no place to leave them.

Yours sincerely,

John R. Setter
Big River Reserve
Shell River P.O.

Sir:

I have to inform you that it has been decided to dispense with the services of Mr. David E. Eastwood, teacher of the Big River Indian Day School, as from the 30th instant.

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan has nominated the services of Miss Cora Merrett to succeed Mr. Eastwood. She has a permanent second class professional certificate for the province of Saskatchewan and considerable teaching experience. Miss Merrett's appointment dates from September first. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $100 per teaching month.

Mr. Inspector Murison, who forwards the nomination in Miss Merrett's case, has been informed of her appointment and requested to arrange that she takes up duties on the date the school will open after the coming summer holidays, viz.: September third, next. I would request that you give her every possible assistance in her work at this school.

I enclose a circular, regarding the dates of the opening and closing of Indian day schools during the next academic year. I shall be pleased if you will hand same to Miss Merrett when she takes up duties.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
L e a s k,
Sask.

Dear Sir,

You will note on the enclosed attendance returns that I did not commence duty until Sept. 7th, thus missing 4 days school.

Dr. Andrews, of the Fellowship of the Maple Leaf, under whose auspices I came to Canada, is over from England, and was to be in P.A. Prince Albert on Sept. 1st, and I wanted to see him.

The dates of his itinerary were changed so that I did not know when I started on my holiday exactly when he was to be there, or I would have written to ask formal permission. As it was I phoned the Agency and was given permission to stay to see him.

I have already made up one day, Labour Day, and should prefer to make up the other three, if necessary, on odd days rather than at Christmas. I shall be glad to know if this meets with your approval.

Yours truly,

Kinoomootayas Day School

Miss Merrit phoned me from Prince Albert and I gave her permission. This letter is a type of her attitude since she went to Big River. I wish you would drop her line informing her to deal direct with me instead of endeavouring to go over my head as she is doing.

March 12th, 1937

To R. A. Hoey Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Dept. Branch, Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith receipts for material purchased for school dinners for the Big River Indian Reserve Day School.

When the grant was reissued last year it was given for this school on a basis of a possible 14 to 15 pupils. I received $30.00 for the winter months with biscuits in addition. This year I was given to understand that the amount would be increased & the biscuits discontinued, so began making school dinners as soon as I returned in Sept., trusting that with careful administration the grant could be made to cover the whole. I continued dinners last year till the end of June, and bought a sack of rice then to finish off the season and to help at the beginning of this. With this and the produce from my own garden I was able to carry on through Sept and part of Oct.

Mr. Davis told me that the Dept. had cut the grant to $5 for this school, though the next school with no more pupils was to get $10, but that he had written to have the matter adjusted as they were still thinking the biscuits were also supplied. The only way to plan at all economically was to buy in sufficient quantities to last the season, which I did. By buying a hind quarter of beef I was able to get it at 6¢ per lb. though this meant cutting up the meat myself.

Potatoes and some meat I purchased from the natives, and used in addition all the potatoes I had grown here, unfortunately not a good crop.

A letter was received later from the agency warning me not to exceed the $5, as no answer was forthcoming to his letter, but by that time the material was purchased. I wrote to the Dept. through Mr. Davis, and eventually received notice that the grant had been increased to $8. per month for 6 months making $40. in all. There were 23 children on the roll till Christmas, with an average of 20. Since Christmas there have been 20 with an average of 18, except for two weeks when some of them were down with the 'flu'.

Knowing the conditions of their homes, and that fish and rabbits were very scarce, during the very cold spell I
was giving the children cocoa on their arrival and a piece of bread when they left. Neither the cocoa, sugar nor bread is included in the receipts and so far has been paid for out of my own pocket.

The dinners are supposed to be discontinued this month which would mean that the children are not even getting one meal a day. I realise the necessity of economy, but surely to neglect the health of the younger generation is the poorest economy. No grant is made on this reserve for a matron, and I have had to pay someone to cook the dinners; neither is there any grant for the issuing of medicines.

The School Inspector's report must be a sufficient comment on the improvement in the pupils on this reserve who have hitherto had a reputation for being too stupid to learn. I am perfectly sure that the marked change is due to the fact that they have been better fed. Practically all the pupils live over two miles from school, some over three, and yet they I think their attendance record will compare favorably with most other reserves.

Surely it is in the interests of economy to build up the health of the younger generation, and it hardly seems right to expect the teacher to bear part of the burden of this. I do not suppose there is any other branch of the civil service where the members contribute anything out of their own salary, at least not those of a salary of $1000. or under.

I am writing to you direct, as minister of Welfare hoping that something definite can be done about the matter. I asked for a grant of $75 for the year, which would have ensured a good daily meal throughout the school year. I shall be glad if you will return the receipts as soon as possible as I believe the accounts have to be in before the end of the month. I delayed writing, hoping to see the agent first but was unable to do so.

Yours truly,

P.S. Lard & Baking Powder have also been paid for by me.
