Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Thank you for your letter of Oct.19th, which I have delayed answering, waiting to hear from Dr. Robinson with regard to the school dinner allowance, as I had a letter from him saying if it were insufficient he would try to get it increased.

No doubt you will remember that last year I was allowed $40. and had a difficulty in getting $4.00 spent in excess of this amount. When I mention that the next reserve, with an attendance very little, if any, higher than ours was getting $55 you will perhaps see one of the causes for disagreement, at least between the agent and teacher on this reserve. This is just one of the many little things.

I received the enclosed Nov. 8th. You will notice that it provides for dinners from Nov. to March only. $10 per month is a sufficient allowance, but why for five months only? The children are just as hungry in Sept and April as in December in fact often more so as often there is no fish to be got then and what few rabbits there were have been trapped in the winter.

As I mentioned when in Ottawa, I would like to give them a drink of hot cocoa before school during the winter. They come two or three miles to school, and are very regular, and I feel that after that walk often in a bitter wind, they need something before beginning work. Then instead of a sweet at noon, I believe a piece of bread and lard or peanut butter at four o'clock is better. $75.00 and biscuits or $100 without biscuits would cover the cost, as I have been able to purchase beans peas etc. at wholesale prices, and by getting a quarter of beef at a time, and cutting it up myself I am able to get it at 7¢ per lb.

The men with children attending school gave me each a sack of potatoes when the agent refused to allow me any out of the community garden. (the gophers got into mine, and in fact the whole garden, whilst I was away) This only meant ten sacks but it showed also that the people do appreciate to some extent what is being done for them.

We have started a manual instruction class this year, but are badly handicapped in that we have no room for a bench, the pupils, three boys, are only 10 and 12 yrs. old and we have no lumber. They have done various repair jobs around the school, including making a new set of steps for the
entrance, out of old lumber. Now they are trying to convert an old packing case into a respectable looking cupboard. At present they are using my tools, and really until we have a new school building it does not seem advisable to launch into anything else.

I do wish it were possible for you to see this same school building. For three years it has been condemned as unsafe. Two years ago it was discovered that the wood in the structure was so rotten that it crumbled when touched, thus doing away with the possibilities of successful repair. The plaster is held in place with unbleached cotton, which is all there is inside the laths to keep out the cold. This wobbles whenever there is a strong wind, and I am in fear of it falling on the children. The wind blows up through the boards like a knife, so that the desks on the wind side have to be dragged away from the walls, thus those children are roasted on the one side and frozen on the other whilst the poor teacher is frozen the whole time as the only possible place for the desk is straight opposite the door, which nothing could make fit, and backing to a wall through which the wind blows on even the calmest day. The toilets, only one of which I have been able to get screened in the three years I have been here, are so old that in spite of constant scrubblings with strong lysol, and the application of lots of lime, they smell most horribly. I know the provincial inspector reports from time to time on the state of the school building but nothing ever seems to come of it, which is still another reason for the appointment of a supervisor for the Indian Dept., though I do realise that the tendency is to cut officials rather than increase them these days.

I wonder, by the way if there is any chance of the Indian Commissioner making any change in the near future. Do you think it would be any use getting in touch with him? So far as the Province is concerned I lost whatever chances I had when I left them for the Indian Dept. I also lost years of service towards pension, as one year with the Indian Dept. cancels all previous years of service under the Provincial Pension Scheme. I hope some time there will be a scheme under the Indian Dept. which will include teachers.

Thank you for the consideration which I feel you gave my previous letter. At present it seems seems advisable to remain where I am, though perhaps in the Spring something better will turn up. The chief drawback here is the isolation. No Officials seem to be able to get any further than Sandy Lake and I find it very difficult to get a companion as there is no white company on the reserve at all. Consequently I live alone. I think however that in the Spring something may be arranged so that I am transferred to a reserve with a farm instructor, and possibly a missionary.

Again with thanks,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

**IMPORTANT** — Before Ordering Read Carefully the Instructions on the Back of This Order Form
EATON Wallpapers for 1938

EATON buyers examined many samples of wallpapers, and chose these that are sent you as the most beautiful and the biggest values the market offered. Order by the number shown on back of each sample.

When decorating, always add borders to walls—be sure to overlap them slightly around the top of walls—nothing improves the appearance of a room so much as a pretty and effective border. Also order ceiling paper to finish room.

Be Sure You Order Enough

Always order a little more paper than you think you need, rather than run short and have the job delayed. Extra wallpaper is almost always needed later for patching, and later shipments of wallpaper sometimes differ slightly in shade in spite of the utmost precaution—another reason why you should be sure and order full requirements to begin with.

All Wallpaper and Ceiling Paper are Sold by the Single Roll

It is put up and sent to you in double rolls for your convenience and economy in cutting. A single roll covers 50 square feet. There are two single rolls in a double roll. Therefore if you order and pay for 10 single rolls, you will receive 5 double rolls.

Border Prices are Quoted for Single Yards

Borders are printed twice on one width of paper—border on the width of paper. Thus if you order 2 yards of border, and it is printed twice on the one width of paper, you will receive 4 yards of border which you would cut down the center, making 2 yards of border. Three printings on one width of paper make 3 yards of border; four printings make 4 yards of border. It is advisable to order 2 extra yards of border to allow for wastage on corners and matching.

How to Measure Your Room Correctly

The number of feet around the room multiplied by its height gives you the number of square feet in the walls. Deduct 20 square feet for each opening, then divide the balance by 30, for the number of single rolls required for walls. For ceiling multiply the length of room by the width, and divide total by 30 for number of single rolls required.

"Sun-Tested"

All the samples marked Sun-Tested are of papers which are printed in fast colors. These papers are dependable and will give you long, durable service.

"Sunworthy"

As the name implies, such a paper assures you that it is practically non-fading—good for years of service.

HELPFUL HINTS TO DO A GOOD JOB

Paper Ceiling First

Always paper ceiling first. Cut each strip 4 inches longer than room length so that 2 inches overlap at each end. This makes the job easier when hanging. Draw a guide line for your first strip by driving a nail 10 inches from sidewall each end of ceiling. Stretch a cord smeared with charcoal or chalk tightly between nails. Pull tight and stretch around against ceiling, leaving an even chalk line.

Matching Strips

Sometimes there is a slight shading in Wallpapers. Examine each roll carefully. Have all the lighter paper on dark side and the darker paper on light side of rooms, doors and windows. This avoids unsightly shadows. Unevenness caused by tapering can be avoided by pasting before trimming. Kalomining and tinting must be washed off with warm water and sponge before papering, and walls should be again cleaned after papering. All surfaces should be well sanded before decorating with wallpaper.

Wooden Walls and Ceilings

Cover with Decorator's Cotton, tacking it about 2 inches from edge and corners before papering. A coat of glue size will shrink it tight to the wood.

Embossed Paper

Embossed or other heavy papers should not be rolled at the corners when hanging. They must be trimmed at both edges and butted instead of overlapped to secure the necessary smoothness.

Treating New Walls

New walls, which have never been papered, should be treated with a thin coat of size. Make by soaking 1 lb. of ground glue in hot water. (Use wallpaper paste if directions on package.) Use Acorn Sizing Glue. Before sizing walls, fill cracks or holes with Paste Patching Plaster mixed to a paste with water. Apply evenly with a brush. Wash walls with warm water. If walls are rough, smooth off projections before sizing; if very rough, apply a thin coat of paste.

For Painted Walls

Remove all grease and oil from these by applying a solution of one part ammonia and six parts water.

Delivery Charges Extra on Wallpaper and Wallpaper Supplies

Please allow sufficient money to cover shipping charges. To estimate weight of your order, figure that Wallpaper weighs approximately 1 lb. per single roll.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a requisition from Miss Cora Merrett of the Big River Indian Day School, for repairs to the school building and residence.

The fence around the building is in very bad condition and certainly needs rebuilding. A water tank was at the school, but in the summer holidays, when the school was closed, the wind blew it away and completely broke it.

The interior of the house has not been done for a period of three years and should be redecorated. A little painting was done only.

This teacher's residence is badly in need of paint on the outside and if there is money available it should be done this year. It will cost $60.00 for paint and $35.00 for labour in order to have this building painted. This residence has not been painted since it was first built. If there is not enough money to paint the building this year then I will include it in the estimates for the coming year; it was not included this year as I felt that there would be sufficient expenditure at this point if a new school was erected as included in our estimates.

Ottawa, June 11, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to repairs required for the school and teacher's residence on the Big River reserve.

In letter of concurrent date, I am advising you regarding the amount available in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the day schools in the Carlton agency. If you recommend the painting at Mistawasis, it would mean that there would only be $110 left in the appropriation. If, however, you recommend the painting at Little Red River, there would be $135 left.

In either event, the amount remaining could be spent at Big River. I am, therefore, returning the list forwarded to you by the teacher, in order that you can decide what items on it you consider are most necessary this year, keeping in mind that the total expenditure must be kept within the appropriation.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

It was my intention, at first, to paint the residence at the Mistawasis school but after checking over the building it was found that the siding would have to be taken off and re-nailed. This condition was due to the fact that nothing has been done on the outside of this building for 16 or 17 years owing to the small amount of money that has been allotted for repairing the day schools and residences of this agency each year.

The Teacher's residence at Big River reserve, the Teacher's residence at the Little Red River Reserve and the school at the same reserve are all fairly good buildings and are the only ones in this agency that could be suitably repaired on the small amount of money granted this year. Sandy Lake School and Residence, of course, will be re-modelled this year as I understand that the Dept. are calling for tenders for this work. The Sturgeon Lake school will do for another year.

Dear Sir:

Re: Big River Indian Day School, Big River Reserve,
Carlton agency.

The above mentioned is a very old School with no accommodation for cooking or serving a meal or other work. Miss Marrett, the teacher has had an old log building moved near the school which she proposes to fix up and use for preparing the midday meal, washing the children's clothing etc.

She is asking for lumber, wire, nails, etc for fixing up this building. A clothes wringer, washing board etc. to be used for washing clothes. A Jubilee Range to be used for cooking the meal and heating the water for washing. The Indians on this Reserve are very backward. It is Miss Marrett's intention that the children have two sets of clothing in order that they may be properly washed and have a clean suit ready for changing, the washing of these clothes to be done at the school under her supervision.

She also proposes to teach the boys carpentry work and is asking tools for that purpose. She also proposes canning meat to be used in the summer when fresh meat is not available. If the funds are at all available I would recommend that her request be granted, as I feel the goods asked for will be put to good use.

The lumber, nails etc., could be purchased from the West Lumber and Supply co., at Debden, Sask. The other goods are from prices in Eaton's catalog. If this request is granted these goods should be supplied at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

As no special provision was made in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements to the Big River school it is practically impossible to provide the amount requested on the purchase requisitions forwarded with your letter.

In addition the school situation on this Reserve is in a nebulous state. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of August 12. The Department does not feel disposed to incur any heavy expenditure at Big River until a final decision is made regarding the school situation on this Reserve.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

Dr. Thos. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, has forwarded to the Department the information which you supplied to him regarding the children of school age on the Big River Indian Reserve.

From the information contained in this letter I am inclined to feel that in making proper provision for the education of the children two day schools should be established, one under Roman Catholic auspices and the other under Anglican auspices. The figures that you have submitted indicate that there are sufficient children for two schools.

Could the present school be renovated in order to provide for the education of the Anglican children? If so, please let me have an estimate of the amount that you believe would be required to place both the school and teacher's living quarters in good condition.

If, however, you consider that it will be necessary to provide a new building for each of the schools please let me know if a log building would be sufficient in each case or if you would recommend a more pretentious building.

In either case it is understood that teacher's living quarters would be provided in connection with each school.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.
If you consider log buildings suitable it is possible that you could arrange to have the logs cut this winter.

Please let me hear fully from you regarding the above suggestions before the end of January as it is possible that we may have some funds on hand from the current year's appropriation which would permit us to purchase at least some of the supplies that would be necessary.

In order to permit us to do so it would be advisable, when you are replying to this letter, to give detailed information regarding the lumber etc. that would be necessary.

It is understood, of course, that you will also give an estimate of the cost of the labour required either in renovating one building and building one new building or in constructing two new buildings.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of January 6th, file 107-3-5, in regard to the building schools at the Big River Reserve; I quite agree that two schools should be established on this Reserve. While there is a lot of children on this Reserve their homes are pretty well scattered and they are hunting Indians and consequently wander quite a bit during the year. Therefore, I do not believe that the attendance at either school will be large but owing to the religious difficulties it would be advisable to build two schools.

In building these schools I believe that schools 18' x 20' would be large enough with a full size basement. At any time, if we found it necessary to close one of the schools, it could be moved to the other site. The teacher's residence that we now have is in fairly good condition though it will need a little bit of decorating. The present school, however, is beyond repair. Therefore, if the proposed plan is carried out, it will be necessary to build two schools and one small residence.

With reference to putting up a log building I do not believe that this would be satisfactory at this point.

I am very busy at the present time but in the course of a few days I will submit the information that you require in regard to the lumber and building materials and also the labour. I am of the opinion that these buildings could be erected cheaper by hiring a foreman and Indian labour than by contract.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer you to previous correspondence in connection with the erection of two day schools on the Big River Indian Reserve.

After carefully considering the situation existing at Big River it is felt that it would be desirable to supply exactly the same accommodation at both schools. This will mean a combined school and teacher's residence for the Church of England pupils and the same type of building for the Roman Catholic pupils.

It is not our intention to erect a residence separate from the school as this involves considerably larger expenditure and the cost of upkeep is also greater.

I am, therefore, returning these lists in order that you can revise them by giving the material needed and the approximate cost of the labour for a combined school and teacher's residence for each denomination.

Dear Sir,

Can you please advise me as to whether it would be wise for me to go away for any length of time during the forthcoming summer vacation.

As I have mentioned before the only time I leave the Reserve is during this period, and last year I could not make any plans as all manner of rumors were rife anent either a transfer or dismissal.

The Indians are all away during the summer, in fact this week there are only five children left to attend school, though the attendance during the year has been good, and this year I had planned to go to Vancouver, and San Francisco, but can find out nothing definite as to buildings etc., except that there are to be the two schools.

I have asked Mr. Davis's advice, and he says 'Go' but as he is leaving in the near future I do not now feel that it is of any real value. I had planned to leave Prince Albert on the 15th of July, but do not know whether I should go ahead with the arrangements or not.

The proposed plans for the buildings which are to be erected are, I believe, to have the residence over the school, and the present residence, which I spent the whole Easter vacation redecorating, removed to another reserve. Mr. Davis tells me that these plans do not include a water system, except one which will necessitate carrying all supplies up from the basement. This would mean carrying every drop of water needed for the house up two flights of stairs. Do you know if such plans have passed as yet? and do please if it is at all possible prevent such arrangements being made. The difference in cost cannot be so very great in comparison with the difference in convenience.

I am so sorry to seem a nuisance, but when eleven months have to be spent in a place with no possible outside interests, comfort and convenience in the house do count for so much.

I am enclosing one of the Grade 5 books.
to give you some idea of the standard of work carried on here.

Five books are being sent for Exhibition at Prince Albert and Regina, together with samples of handwriting needlework, laundry, and handicraft. Most of the handicraft of the older boys has consisted of keeping the school buildings in running repairs, as I have had neither convenient place, nor tools for a real course of carpentry, together with the garden. As they have only been in school four years, and the oldest is only 13, I really am rather proud of their progress, particularly as every girl has an apron for domestic science, in addition to other personal garments including stockings and mitts made as part of the school routine.

You will possibly notice, from the English exercises in the enclosed book, that we were able, with no outside help, to make the trip to Saskatoon to see their majesties. It was really quite an interesting experience.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Miss Merrett:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 19th instant, in which you seek information with respect to your vacation of this year and the building of the schools on the reserve.

The question of whether you should leave the reserve or not at this time is a matter in respect to which we can give you little advice. We can assure you, however, that no change is contemplated at your school and that ample notice will be given you when a change is decided upon. It is unfortunate in my judgment that you are at all influenced by rumors that may be in circulation from time to time on the reserve. A school teacher can afford to ignore such rumors at all times and be governed wholly by the instructions that reach her from time to time through official sources.

The actual construction of Indian day schools comes under the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the Department. I have not seen, nor have I had an opportunity to study, the plans prepared for the construction of the two schools on the Big River reserve. I am of the opinion, however, that these plans will be somewhat similar to the standard plans prepared for the construction of such schools throughout the Dominion. Indian day schools built in recent years are up to date and convenient in every -

Miss Cora Merrett,
Teacher,
Big River Indian Day School,
Shell River P. O.,
Saskatchewan.
every sense. The Missionary from Berens River, where a school was built last year, writes:

"The Indian day school erected last year is perfect. It is all that an Indian day school should be".

If you have any representations to make to the Agent with respect to conveniences that might be installed, I feel sure the Agent will give them sympathetic consideration. In the case of the Big River schools, it is altogether likely that the actual construction work may be undertaken by the Surveys and Engineering Branch, under the direction of the local Indian Agent.

I am returning herewith the books sent forward with your communication. The work of the pupils appears to be very neat and in my judgment very creditable. It is my hope that sufficient space will be provided in the basement of the new school for the organization of worthwhile handicraft projects.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of June 2nd, file 107-3-5, enclosing a plan for the proposed schools and residences at Big River Reserve, would it be possible to have the Engineering Branch estimate the material required for these buildings? I am leaving on the 21st to pay Annuity in the north and will be away for about two weeks; and on my return will be very busy as the work on the Reserves and in the office will be far behind. With reference to the plan, I feel that each school large enough for 20 pupils should be sufficient. One bedroom for the teacher is not going to be very satisfactory as the teachers require a room for use as a kitchen as well as a bedroom. Yours truly,

July 19, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant enclosing requisitions for the material required in the erection of the two schools on the Big River Reserve.

You may arrange for the purchase of the following for each school:

- 35 Yards sand
- 20 " gravel
- 100 Lbs. hay wire

1-7" adjustable thimble for brick chimney
1-6" adjustable thimble for brick chimney

The blackboard will be ordered from the Government Stationery Office. The other items on the requisition are being ordered by the Purchasing Branch and they are being requested to rush delivery.

Funds for the Big River C.E. school were provided in the main appropriation, while funds for the R.C. school were voted in the special supplementaries. Consequently, two separate cheques for $1000.00 each are being forwarded to you and you should forward separate accountable vouchers for these advances.

A supply of labour return forms will also be sent to you.

The Department will depend on you to see that the buildings erected are sufficiently large to accommodate the number of pupils that will probably attend them. In a report dated December 24, 1938, Dr. Robertson,

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.
Inspector of Indian Agencies, stated that the number of Catholic children on the Big River Reserve between the ages of 7 and 16 was 35, and the number of Anglican children on the Reserve between the same ages was 28. I mention this because in your letter of June 19 you stated that you considered that a school large enough for 20 pupils would be sufficient in each case.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

The Department is erecting on the Big River Reserve two new day schools.

I attach requisition for the materials required for the Big River C.E. day school and I also attach a requisition for the materials required for the R.C. day school. This latter requisition states that the same materials are required for the R.C. day school as are requested for the C.E. day school.

It is important that the materials for both schools be ordered at the earliest possible date and I should appreciate it if you would give the matter immediate attention.

You will note that there is one requisition for the heavier material including the lumber and another requisition for the paint and hardware.

Director.

Dear Sir,

As you know our mission and school building at our reserve is now complete and our missionary, Rev. W.S. Moore, is expecting to open school on the 12th of this month. Dear Sir,

The Committee which has charge of the Indian Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the North West has instructed me to invite your attention to the Indian Boarding School which we have reopened at Lakesend, adjoining Pasqua's Reserve, and I am to say that although at present we ask for no financial assistance for the school, we would be pleased if the Indian Department would take the Institution under its supervision and have the Agent and Inspectors include it in their visits.

The school has now an attendance of seventeen children, of whom some four or five are white children who attend as day pupils. Of the others, some are the children of parents who are not in treaty relations, but who are as destitute and as ignorant as the majority of Indians, and others are children who have been refused admission to the Regina School, or who are not capable of being admitted to that school on account of constitutional disease. It is our intention to give special attention to children of this latter class. The Principal of the school, the Rev George Arthur,
B... has taken three sessions of a medical course, and he is assisted by a Matron who is a trained nurse. We hope, therefore, to do what such appliances are capable of doing for the rescue and restoration to health of children who otherwise would very likely be extremely short lived.

At the time of my visit to the school a few days ago there were only two children on the roll who were available for admission to the Regina or any other Industrial School, and it is hoped that the parents of these children may soon be so accustomed to separation from them that it will be possible to persuade them to allow the little ones to be taken to Regina.

In accordance with an interview which I had with you when you were last in Winnipeg, we are counting upon the favorable presentation of the case which you promised to make to secure an increase of the grant to the Birtle School, so that we will receive support for 40 children, which number the building can easily accommodate, instead of for 25 as at present.

Recognising that we are wards of the nation, this letter is not to be construed as an expression of criticism directed against the Department; we are appealing to you for help and from those that are guarding the interests of the Indians.

For the past fifty years our residential schools have been ill the hands of religious denominations, a clause in the Indian Act classifies the Indians in two classes, Roman Catholic and Protestant. Education being compulsory, the law leaves us no alternative, it forces us to place our children in a religious school from the age of seven to sixteen. From childhood they are taught that religious laws are of first importance, religious duties enter their daily life, classroom work and academic learning is sadly neglected, concentration of thought, strengthening of will power and mental power are not taught them, therefore gradually coming under complete subjugation of religious authorities, as a result they lose the quality of character, integrity and manhood.

Therefore we suggest that you provide us with a day school, so as to enable the Indians to assume responsibility for raising their children. By this method the Indian children would be raised in the environment in which they will eventually have to make their living.
Under the present system after a child have been in a boarding school for ten years they are completely unfit to take their place in the life of the reserve, also they are not sufficiently educated to compete with the white man off the reserve in any trade or profession.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

Re: Attached Letter, Delegation, Pasque and Muscowpetung Bands, School.

I might say that there is constant agitation among the Indians of these Bands for the establishment of day schools. They object to sending their children to residential schools. They want them at home. I have, however, pointed out to them that I could hold out no hope for the establishment of day schools on their reserves for some time to come, and that in view of the war situation, it would be impossible to find funds for the purpose. They, however, insisted that I submit their proposition to you.

There is no doubt that this school could be established in the present building at a small saving to the Department. It would, however, only accommodate about ten children, and immediately it was started, nearly every family on the reserves would want to send their children there, and those who could not send them would consider they were discriminated against. Consequently it would be a constant source of trouble.

Personally, I feel it would be a great mistake to establish a school on these reserves until such time as one could be built that would accommodate all the children who would wish to attend it.

I beg to say that Cote Band of Indians had a council meeting last week, regarding school for their reserve. The band was divided in opinions in this matter, some wanting a day school similar to the regular public school, while others wanted a combined day and boarding school. After considerable discussion a vote was taken and it was decided by a small majority in favor of the combined day and boarding school. The Principal of the Crowstand Boarding School told me that they had decided to sell entire school property including buildings and land at the present site and build a new school on the reserve.

The Indians, however, express a strong wish that the school be built and run by the Department and not in any way controlled or managed by the Church. The Band desire as soon as possible, when all come definitely located on their lands, to change the school into a regular public school, towards which they are willing to contribute a sum equal in amount to that paid by neighboring white people in school taxes. If the Department agrees to their request the Indians are willing to do the labor on the New School building, the Department to furnish the material, at such time as a public school is started.

The Band has submitted through the chief Inspector conditions on which they are willing to surrender the southern portion of their reserve, which will if accepted bring them much closer together and make the School convenient for fact they will be near enough together to make a public school feasible. I beg to ask that I be informed as soon as reply to convey to the Indians,

Dear Mr. Scott,

The matter of a combination Day and Boarding School on Cote Reserve, is one that I should like to bring to your notice. As you are aware, the question of building a new school at Crowstand has been under consideration for the last three years, but during that time conditions on the Cote Reserve have greatly changed, owing to the greater part of it having been surrendered, and the Band living on the remainder of it now form a thickly settled community. I am of the opinion that a combination Day and Boarding school would work here to perfection, as fully 70% of the children on the reserve could attend as Day pupils and the balance as Boarders for five days each week.

I may say that the Indians of this Band have been very anxious to have a day school and complain about the present school, which as you know is not popular with them.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st inst., which was found here on my arrival on the 28th inst.

I note that the school is to be in charge of Miss Walker, Teacher, at a salary of $450.00, and Miss Sarah Dunbar at $500.00 per year. As the management of this school will have to be under one head and as your letter does not say which one of the two ladies is to be in charge I would be glad to be advised on this point.

Your letter does not say anything about boarding arrangements for the pupils and I am therefore in the dark on this subject, although I understand from Mr. McWhinney, the missionary, that he understood from the Church Authorities that the Department were to furnish everything. If this is the case I would like to have full instructions on the matter.

I have a few suggestions to make to the Department on the subject of this school. I think it is highly essential that the Indian Agent who is responsible for the Agency should be the one to give instructions to those in charge of the school.

D.C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
There should be no divided authority in this matter. If Mr. McWhinney or anyone else has suggestions to make regarding the school he should make them to the Agent and not to the school. I am merely pointing this out so as to avoid friction in the future which there is bound to be unless this matter is clearly understood at the outset.

All correspondence regarding this school should come through the Agent.

There is another matter that I think I should bring to your attention. The school is small and there is not sleeping accommodation for more than four children at the most. This being the case I think every effort should be made to have all children attend as day pupils, and those children who live at a great distance from the school should be sent to regular boarding schools where there is ample accommodation waiting for them. I refer to File Hills boarding school and Brandon Industrial school. Of course there will perhaps be cases where it would be a hardship to send children away to boarding schools but these will be few and on the advice and recommendation of the Agent they could be admitted to the improved Day school as boarders. Once we begin taking in boarders the expense of management will be increased and I feel it will be only a short time before you will be called upon to supply nearly everything that is supplied boarding schools and the training not nearly so good.

If the idea of supplying a mid-day meal only is followed, it will save a lot of complications and work for the Agent as we will only have to purchase meat, rice, biscuits, tea and sugar, whereas on the other hand if regular boarders are kept we will have to have all the facilities as are kept at a boarding school including additional staff, horses, cows, hens etc.,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6281, file 604-1, part 1)
The mid-day meal system worked out well at the Assiniboine Agency and if the people who are to take charge of this school will do as well there will be no grounds for complaint. My idea is to impress on the management of this school that it is to be run as a day school and let the boarding schools do what cannot be done here.

Another matter that I am not clear about, and that is regarding the board and maintenance of Miss Walker and Miss Dunbar. I understood from Mr. McWhinney that the Church Authorities proposed that the ladies provide their own board, I only hope this is true as it will be much easier for the Agent not to look after the purchase of the various requirements, of course there will be beef, flour and the other staples that will have to be purchased for the pupils' mid-day meal and these articles could be supplied to the staff as well as it would be impossible to keep them separate from the pupils' rations.

With regard to the furnishings required for the new school your instructions to me were to purchase what was absolutely necessary to equip the school. I did not find anything in the list of furnishings on hand at Crowstand that I thought would be suitable except a few blankets. I have therefore purchased a range, which I am having installed before I leave here, and the necessary cooking utensils. I could not get any beds or furniture in town, there being only one store here where furniture is sold and this shop carried practically nothing. I will order the beds, mattresses and two cheap bedroom sets in Winnipeg.

The class-room furnishings, desks etc., I am having transferred from Crowstand School at once, and will have the carpenter place them in the new school. A new desk and a small cupboard for school material will have to be supplied for this room.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

We have just learned that the new school on the Cote Indian Reserve is completed, and that Miss A. E. Walker is to be the teacher, and Miss S. Dunbar the matron. We understand there are to be a number of boarding pupils - perhaps eight or ten. I presume we may regard this as a sort of semi-boarding school.

How is the school to be maintained? Who is to have oversight of it? Will Miss Walker have charge of the institution, and next to her will the Indian Agent exercise direct control over the school, or will our missionary, Rev. W. McWhinney, continue to have general oversight? If the supervision of Mr. McWhinney is withdrawn, it would seem that the only connection the Church will have with the school will be the privilege of submitting the name of a teacher and a matron for the approval of the Government.

In the estimates sent here, the salary of Miss Walker is placed at $450 and board, and that of Miss Dunbar, $500 and board. What will they receive to cover board? In a communication just received, it is suggested that, if they are to be provided with beef, flour, tea, etc., an allowance of $100 would be sufficient, but, if they have to provide everything themselves, $200 should be allowed.

How will the salaries be paid? Will the Department forward the money in a lump sum to Dr. Somerville, our Church Treasurer, in the same manner as the other salaries are advanced? As this school is not just like any of the others in which our Church is interested, we would be glad to know your plans.
We have not had an opportunity as yet to bring this matter either before the Presbytery of Yorkton or our Board, but feel sure that both would prefer that Mr. McWhinney should have general oversight. As he is a Minister of our Church, through him the Presbytery could keep in touch with the work. This is very essential, if we are to have any connection with the school. I fancy the women are not anxious for responsibility, but would prefer to be workers under our Board as heretofore.

In looking over past correspondence, I find that on November 16th, 1915, you wrote to Dr. Grant as follows:

"I think the suggestion to retain the services of Miss Walker, that Miss Dunbar should be matron and that Mr. McWhinney should have a general supervision of the school and mission work on the reserve, is a good one, and I am prepared to give it my approval".

Then, in a later letter dated December 4th, 1915, you said:

"It is thought that it would be advisable to continue classes in the boarding school building for day pupils until such time as the new day school building is ready for occupation, and I should be glad if you would instruct Mr. McWhinney, who is to supervise this school, accordingly".

These statements seem to us very clear, and the arrangement you have outlined would be satisfactory, but, as we have had correspondence from Saskatchewan recently intimating that the Government is planning to work otherwise, we would be glad to hear from you again.

Yours sincerely,

J.H.E.-A.V.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have this morning a letter from Miss E. A. Walker at Cote Indian School in regard to her salary, and also that of Miss Dunbar, matron.

Miss Walker claims that her understanding was that she was to receive $450 with board, room and laundry in addition, and that Miss Dunbar was to receive $500 and board, etc. It now appears that, since moving into the new school, practically the full cost of board has come out of the salaries of these ladies.

For example, the Hurricane Hills School was vacant for three months. This school was opened during December 1916 and school was taught six days during that month before closing for Christmas holidays and was re-opened on January 2nd, 1917. The attendance for January has been rather irregular owing to the severe cold weather and a number of the children have suffered from La Gippe, but I expect the attendance will be of a better average as soon as the weather moderates as the majority of the parents are anxious to send their children to school. Quite a number of the children attending this school previously attended Crowstand School and apparently, what they were then taught, does not seem to be of much benefit to them now. For example, one boy, a lad about 15, who had attended Crowstand School for four years cannot yet read satisfactorily from the 2nd primary reader. The teacher and matron are using their best endeavours but the school has not been in operation long enough to observe any progress.

Considerable inconvenience has been experienced during the recent severe cold weather by inability to heat the building as the furnace is far from satisfactory. Yesterday, Feb. 2nd., it became necessary to dismiss school about 1.30 o'clock as it was too cold for the children to stay in the building despite repeated efforts by the staff and others to produce heat. Mr. Kelly examined it and he informed me that all the pipe work to the furnace would have to be altered in order to get satisfactory results, but he does not wish to undertake the alteration until spring.

With reference to Mrs. S. Marshall, teacher of the Cote Improved Day School, I beg to draw your attention to the fact that Mr. S. Marshall is a very competent and experienced teacher, has the children well in hand, and I have noticed a great improvement in the children in their work, cleanliness and deportment.

The number of children on the roll is 38 and the average attendance is 25.9 which does not include the daily attendance of four white children of the Farm Instructor's, so it can readily be seen keeps Mrs. Marshall fully employed.

This teacher is in receipt of a salary of $750.00 only per year, and I am of opinion that it should be raised by $200.00 per year. Her services are valuable to the Department, and am fully convinced that her services should be recognised.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Mr. McKenzie, Indian Agent has told me of a letter which he has just received from you saying that it is not possible for us to keep boarding children in the Cote Day School. I expect to be in Regina next week and would like to discuss this whole matter with you but in the meantime I would like you to consider the following matters in connection with this question:

1. When the decision was arrived at to close the Crowstand Boarding School and substitute a day school I foresaw that there would be children who would not have suitable homes and others who would be too far away to come and go each day and therefore you will remember that I asked that a small boarding school be attached to the day school. This plan was approved by yourself and by the Department at Ottawa and the plans for the building were drawn and sent to me in 1915. But I suppose it was due to war time economy that the boarding idea was dropped and the Improved Day School was built instead. You will recollect that there was space enough to provide for five bed rooms. It has always been my idea that these should be used for those children who were too far away to come each day so that they could stay at the school from Monday till Friday. However the need for this did not become acute until this spring when the building and opening of the St. Phillips boarding school raised new problems.

2. On the Keskoose Reserve, not far from the new school, there are several protestant families, some of whose children had been attending the St. Phillips day school. When the day school closed and was to be replaced by the new boarding school these protestant children could not attend as protestants. Efforts were at once put forth by the priest in charge to get them to have their children baptized in the Roman Catholic faith and so be admitted to the school. The only other alternative was for their children to be sent away to File Hills or elsewhere. To this they were strongly opposed and you can see the lesser this provided for the R.C. Church to get possession of these children.

3. I should say here that I foresaw these difficulties two years ago when I first heard of the probable building of this boarding school. At that time I wrote the Deputy Minister Mr. Scott pointing out that the number of Catholic families on the Keskoose Reserve was so small that to build this school there would mean encroachment on our work and consequent friction and trouble for the officials of the Department. He promised that my representations would be considered but whether they were or not I do not know.

4. When the question as to what should be done with these protestant children became acute in March and April I told the parents that until some satisfactory arrangement could be made we would take them into the Cote School from Monday till Friday. Father Bruet represented to the parents that this was merely a scheme to get them down to Cote School and then send them away to File Hills or elsewhere without the parents consent. Because of this supposed danger two families formerly protestant had their children baptized and in the case of one family two girls were admitted to the St. Phillips School. The mother of these girls is a member of our Church and the father is a nominal protestant. In the case of two other families we took their four children to Cote School and have been keeping them there from Monday till Friday. At the same time I
took the matter up with Rev. Arthur Barner and Dr. Manning in Toronto. I was going to write you in regard to the matter but understood you were not at home. I thought it best therefore to act through the officials of the Church.

6. Not only on Kesekoose Reserve has the R.C. Church been trying to get protestant children into their school but their agents have been down on Cote Reserve trying to get those children who had a considerable distance to go to seek admission to St. Phillips.

6. While there was Day Schools on both Cote and Kesekoose Reserves there was equality of opportunity. Since the building of the new boarding school on Kesekoose our work is placed at a decided disadvantage. What I have been asking for is that some action be taken by the Indian Department to place the educational work of both Churches on an equal footing. We do not ask for any favours but we do ask for equal facilities for doing our work.

7. The Indians on Cote Reserve have been asking that the Day School be turned into a boarding school. I have discouraged this as much as possible in the past but now it seems as if some such action should be taken. I would not ask it to be made into a full fledged boarding school but that the buildings be sufficiently enlarged to enable us to keep from Monday till Friday those Cote children who have too far to come to and from each day and those protestant children from Kesekoose who are still farther away. Another solution that has been talked of is to provide vans to convey the children to and from school. This plan has had difficulties where it has been tried elsewhere. If the children are boarded from Monday till Friday some system would have to be evolved of providing food supplies for them.

8. I know that the easiest solution of all would be to have these children go to Millarville or some other boarding school under our Church. I would be quite satisfied and pleased if the parents would agree to this but they are extremely unwilling to have their children sent away. To try to force this would be the means of driving them into the R.C. School.

I shall be in Regina next week attending Conference and shall try to see you and discuss this whole matter. The information in this letter will give you my viewpoint pretty fully in the meantime.

In conclusion let me say that I do not want to raise any difficulties for the Indian Department, but I do want something done which will be fair to all concerned.

With very kind regards, I am,

Yours Respectfully,

(Sgd) W. McWhinney.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your No. 117-2-1, of the 19th instant, in reply to mine of the 15th October, with which I enclosed a copy of letter from the Rev. Mr. McWhinney with reference to the Dote Indian Day School and the providing of additional accommodation for children remaining at the school from Monday to Friday, and reply to say that, personally, I do not see the necessity for this. The Inspectors have been visiting this school regularly for the last 12 years, and this is the first time such a plan has been suggested by anybody. This school was built as an Improved Day School, with facilities to provide a midday meal for children coming from a distance, and it should be maintained as such. We have a similar school at Fisher River, even larger than this, and there is not a resident child in it, although the conditions are equally as difficult as at Pelly. We also have an Improved Day School at Fairford, where we have children living at considerable distances from the school and there are no children resident there. If we provide for the accommodation of 12 or 14 children in this school, as Mr. McWhinney suggests, there being six kept there now, we are getting into a Boarding School of a kind that is not advisable. You will recall that the Government, at considerable expense, built a splendid school at File Hills. This school was not built for the File Hills Indians only. We could not maintain a school with the children from this point alone. Pelly was to be one of the main recruiting points, and a large number of the pupils in the File Hills School today are from Pelly, but if we establish a sort of half industrial boarding school there we are going to cut off the feeding ground for this school and the children.

Dear Mr Perrier,-You will remember the conversation we had last July, on the occasion of your visit to the Cote Day School in regard to improved accommodation for the pupils who are in residence from Monday until Friday. Last autumn I wrote a letter to the Agent asking that he urge upon the Department the need for something being done in this matter before winter. I understand the letter with an accompanying one from the Agent went to the Commissioner's Office in Regina and I suppose was sent on to you. However nothing has yet been done and as a result the matron has had to make sleeping accommodation in the dining room for three or four boys all during the winter. This room has therefore to serve for dining room, dormitory and wash room. Surely the Department does not wish such conditions continued any longer than is necessary.

Your suggestion of last summer that we erect a separate building to serve as a dining room and use the present dining room as a dormitory is I think the best solution of the difficulty. I would urge than a competent builder or architect be sent as soon as possible to decide where this additional building should be put up and how it should be connected to the main building.

As I pointed out to yourself personally and to the Deputy Minister by letter, the conditions which make this necessary are not of our making. Until the St Philips School was opened it was an easy matter to send children who could not attend as day pupils to File Hills or some other boarding school. But now inducements are offered to get them into St Philips and we have to meet that competition with suitable accommodation right here.

Whenever the parents are willing we are quite satisfied to have them go to one of our boarding schools. We do not want to build up a boarding system here any more than we can help, but for years to come there will always be a dozen or more children who will need to be accommodated at the Cote School from Monday until Friday.

Some provision in the way of fire escape should also be made for the upstairs rooms in the present building. There should also be six single cots provided when the proposed addition is erected.

I sincerely hope these matters will receive prompt attention from the Department, since by this time you will also have received Mr Inspector Hamilton's report on the same matter.

I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Replying to the letter No. IIP-2-I dated June 5th from the Secretary, Mr. McLennan, I wish to express my surprise at the view taken by the Department in regard to the matter of increased accommodation at the Cote Improved Day School. It seemed to me when you were here last July that you were fully impressed with the need of the better accommodation for which we have been asking and in the letter referred to above no sufficient reason is given for the refusal of our request. We have no wish to establish a boarding school on the reserve but we feel that accommodation should be provided for those children who are too far away to attend as day pupils. I am quite pleased to have these children go to Brandon or File Hills but when the parents refuse to send them two alternatives remain, either to remain at home and be deprived of education or be coerced into going to St. Phillips boarding School. At the present time there are several children eight or nine years old who are not attending any school because they are too far away to attend as day pupils.

As I pointed out in my previous letter the present conditions here are not of our making. They are due to the Department refusing our request in 1918 for suitable buildings for our work and then allowing the St. Phillips School to be built a few miles away when there was only a very small number of children in the immediate neighborhood to be accommodated. We might well ask why it is fit and proper to have a full fledged boarding school on the Kusekoo Reserve but unwise to give boarding accommodation for even a few children on the Cote Reserve. To me this does not look like treating alike the two Churches involved.

In conclusion let me say that I have enough confidence in the desire of the Departmental officials to be just in the matter that I believe if they take time to look at this question fairly reasonably they would promptly grant our request.

I shall hope to hear from you more favourably in regard to this matter in the near future.

I Am,
Yours Respectfully,

Sir,

Dear Sir:-

I find it necessary to report that the work of Miss R. M. Jamieson, teacher of the Cote Indian Day School, is not very satisfactory, and while I am not in favour of making the change immediately, the matter would be kept in mind and the change made at the beginning of the next school term.

She is sadly lacking in discipline. There has been considerable truancy and she does not seem to be able to control them in the classroom. I find that it is impossible to get any of the children, those who have been attending for several years and those who have recently started, to speak above a whisper in the classroom.

In addition to this, she has a great deal of spare time which could be spent in social service work and things of this nature. This she will not do. You will remember our conversation Tuesday night about the affairs at this school and the movement which I mentioned with regard to transferring Mrs. Roy and appointing a man as a missionary with his wife for teacher. As I informed you, I do not think this is what is required at all, but what is required is the right kind of a classroom teacher who will co-operate with Mrs. Roy, both in and about the school itself and on the reserve in social service work.

There is no need for any expense to the Department outside of the salary which is now being paid, but there is need for the teacher's salary being paid to the right kind of a person.

I have previously hesitated about reporting adversely in connection with Miss Jamieson, chiefly because two or my own children are attending this school and it might be thought that this is my chief interest. My own children are making fair progress, but they receive no discipline whatever in school and it is necessary for us to attend to that part of it ourselves. The Indian children, however, receive no discipline whatever at home, and it is therefore very necessary that they receive some at the school.

Yours very truly,

Thos. Robertson, D.S., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Sgd. J.P.B. Ostrander.

Memorandum:

MR. JACKSON:

Re: Operation of Cote Improved Indian Day School.

Immediately following our discussion of a few days ago, I made a careful review of the letters and reports on file in respect to the operation of the Cote Indian Day School.

I should explain that the Cote School was established by Mr. Graham, as an experiment, a few years prior to his retirement. Mr. Graham was of the opinion at that time that it might be possible to operate a school in which provision would be made for the board and lodging of the pupils from Monday until Friday, asking the parents to become responsible for the clothing of the children and for their care during the week-ends.

At the time the present teacher and his wife were appointed, a number of children were boarded at the school from Monday until Friday of each week and the teacher's wife was allowed a salary of $50.00 a month for a 9 month period, on the understanding that she would be responsible for the preparation of the meals for these children and their general care. Two female teachers had been in charge of this school for several years prior to the appointment of the present teacher. The arrangement whereby pupils were provided with board and lodging at the school from Monday until Friday was never wholly satisfactory and was recently abandoned. The keeping of children at the school while others were permitted to go home at the close of the regular school period from day to day created a certain amount of dissatisfaction. It is
significant that so far as I am aware no country has ever been able to organize what one might term an intermediate school, half-way between the residential school and the ordinary day school.

You will note that the reports on the teacher now in charge of the Cote Indian Day School are excellent in every respect. It is my understanding that this teacher taught for the full 10 months period last year, although under no obligation to do so. I have just learned that Mr. and Mrs. Dobbin may be offered the principalship of either the Round Lake or the File Hills Residential School. If such is the case it will only be necessary in the future to employ one teacher at the Cote School. The reports on file indicate that this teacher and his wife enjoy a very high reputation in the United Church. They have spent their lives in non-English speaking communities and Mrs. Dobbin particularly has been very successful in the organization and conduct of Sunday Schools amongst central European peoples.

I got the impression from my conversation with Mr. Bryant that he is not very favourably impressed with the work of this teacher. Mr. Bryant finds it difficult to understand why his wife should be paid $50.00 a month as matron. This payment can be easily understood if we keep in mind the organization of the school and the purpose for which it was originally established. I personally attach a great deal of importance to Inspector Waind's report. Mr. Waind's reports are usually very critical and Mr. Dobbin appears to be one of the few teachers whose work appears satisfactory from year to year to the Inspector.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 20th, File 117-2-1 in connection with the transfer of Mr. L. L. Dobbin to principalship of File Hills Residential School and appointment of a successor for Cote Improved Indian Day School.

I recall discussing Cote Day School when visiting your Department during the winter and am of the opinion that as far as the actual school teaching at Cote Day School is concerned, one teacher is all that is required. I believe I pointed out that Mr. Buck at Aey Day School taught almost as many pupils as attended Cote Day School, and that Mrs. Buck also prepared a noon day lunch for all the children with an allowance for supplies amounting to half that supplied to Cote Day School, and she received no payment whatever for this work, while at Cote Mr. and Mrs. Dobbin both received salaries. In discussing the matter I maintained that Mrs. Buck should also be entitled to some monthly compensation.

A field matron working with the teacher, really interested in the spiritual and bodily welfare of the Indians who would spend a good part of the time out on the reserve, visiting the homes and encouraging and helping the mothers to better living conditions, improving sanitation, giving simple first aid instruction in the care of the sick babies, etc., could, I think do a great deal of good on this Cote Reserve. There are a few homes that are farther than three miles from school, and an active matron should be able to visit every home frequently on foot, without any great hardship.

It has been said here that the Catholics are converting the United Church members to their faith, with possibly some truth, but more real active missionary work on the part of those in charge of the work here would overcome this to a great extent. I would suggest the organization of a good Sunday School Service every Sunday instead of the regular Sunday Service which is attended by the faithful few each Sunday. The Sunday School Service could in time include an adult Bible class, which I think would be attended by many adult Indians, with one or two that would be glad to teach a class. We possibly cannot do a great deal with many of the old Indians, but with the school children and younger people, there are great possibilities of helping them morally.........
them morally and spiritually.

In conclusion I would say that it would be possible to carry on here with one teacher for the duration of the war providing some provision is made for the preparation of the noon day meal. It would, I expect, be necessary for the teacher to keep a maid for help and company.

Regarding the missionary work about on the reserve, I have already stated my views. By the way, I understand from Mr. Dobbin that the new missionary is on the way here from Toronto, and is expected to arrive to-morrow or the next day.

Re Cote Day School, Cote Reserve:

The Rev. Miss Corner has been in charge of Cote Day School since July last, assisted by Miss M. Rogers as Matron. The latter has had many years in various mission fields and proved to be capable and understanding and she was very well liked by everybody. Unfortunately her health has not been good. She had a heart condition which made it necessary for her to take periods of rest and finally the doctors insisted that she give the work up. She went East last week.

Miss Corner has made little if any headway with the mission work. She is of a more or less retiring nature and does not appear to get in common contact with the Indians, especially the men who are not generally in favour of a woman preacher. As a teacher she works hard, puts in hours after school on preparation of desk work etc., but does not appear to have the special ability to make a good teacher. She also has had difficulty in handling the larger boys. Miss Rogers had practically assumed all the responsibility of conducting the school and now that Miss Corner is left to her own resources, I am afraid she will find the situation difficult.

Miss Corner is a woman of splendid character, trying to do her best, but in my opinion a man should be on the job, although many women teachers could handle the school very well.

Miss Rogers was going to talk the situation over with Miss Lovies of the Women's Missionary Society at Toronto when she returned as Miss Rogers also realized that a man on the job would be much better for the mission work as well as the school teaching. A married couple with the man to teach and preach would, I think, be the best arrangement of this Cote Day School if this could be arranged with the W.M.S.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Re: Cote School

I visited this institution on Saturday morning, the 26th instant and naturally there were no children there at that time, but I went over the place and had a long talk with the Rev. Miss Corner, who is the teacher there.

The school is in fair shape but there are a certain number of repairs that will have to be made - for instance; a new cistern in the basement. I was informed, and I saw the cistern, that it has gotten full of little holes. This was caused by the pipe gradually rusting. The furnace is also in bad shape. This was a misfit in the first place and 28 years ago I wrote reams of letters regarding this furnace and I finally got it changed so that it would heat the school. Mr. Bryant is going to get Mr. Barrie from Pelly, who is a tinsmith, to look at the furnace and the cistern, also some eave-troughing that has fallen off the school, and find out what it will cost to effect the repairs.

The fence around the school also needs repairing. Probably all new posts will have to be put in. Mr. Bryant will also attend to this in due course.

..... The attendance
The attendance at the school is what caught my attention. There are 29 on the register and I suppose a lot more of school age that are not registered, but the attendance would I do not suppose average 15 during the year. However, the Department have that information. I talked very seriously on the matter of attendance with Miss Corner and she admitted frankly that she had done her best to get the Indians to attend but just simply could not awaken them to the fact that their children had to come to school to get an education. For instance; she informed me that the two that were her star pupils in attendance had lost 17½ days during the year. Others stayed away for days and days at a time. In fact these are her exact words "if the children want to stay at home the Mothers will let them do so" and you know the result. I talked to Mr. Bryant, the Agent, on this matter and he made the statement that he did not try to encourage the older boys to attend school as Miss Corner could not handle them. The Rev. Miss Corner seemed to be quite a fine woman but she may not have the necessary qualifications for making a good teacher. No doubt she has the education, but whether she has the qualities to pass this on to the children is more than I know. However, to start with the management of the school is not what it should be. As you know this is what they call an Improved Day School. Five bedrooms upstairs and several rooms downstairs. It has a large furnace where cordwood sticks are used. In fact I think the furnace box is 48" long. Miss Corner

... told me herself
she herself that it was an awful job for her to put on the furnace. In her own words she stated—"I have to drag the sticks over to the furnace and then get some of the children to help me put them into the fire box. As a result the school was terribly cold last winter and never got warm until night.

The other lady that was at the school broke down about three months ago and had to go east.

You know probably better than I do, because I am not a teacher, that children do not get much of an education unless they go to school more or less regularly. Therefore you might say that the way the school is going at the present time, with only 50% attendance, it is more or less of a joke.

I had an opportunity of speaking to one of the Councillors before I left there, John Felly, who has a fairly good education and speaks good English and I asked him to speak to the band and tell them that unless these Indians sent their children more regularly to school it would probably be necessary for our Department to close up the Institution, and John realized this. Whether my advice to him will be followed by the other Indians or not I do not know. He was the only one I had an opportunity of speaking to as I left in the afternoon.

I realize that teachers are very hard to get, but whoever is there it takes a man to fire the furnace.

The repairs that are necessary will be taken up later.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

In the above connection, please be advised that on the 18th instant, J.L. BRYANT, Indian Agent, contacted the writer and complained that Miss Elizabeth ROBERTSON, Cote Day School teacher, was having difficulty maintaining regular attendance of her pupils at school. Mr. BRYANT advised that no Attendance officer had ever been appointed on the reserve in question and he requested that police action be taken under section 10 of the Indian Act.

At 9:00 AM this date, the writer patrolled via Pol/Car Code 6560 to the Cote Reserve, where I went over the subject with J.L. BRYANT. I suggested that it might be advisable to have a truant officer appointed, if the matter was likely to need much attention. The principle offenders appeared to be the children of Campbell SHINGOOS, John PELLY, George Bell COPE, Victor SHINGOOS, James SHINGOOS, Roy SHITSHAW and Allan FIDDLER, all twenty Indians.

Heavy rains on this date made it impossible to travel the reserve trails by car, and it was decided that it would probably suffice at the moment, if I contacted the teacher in question, and warned what students that happened to be in attendance this date as to their future behaviour. I found only six students in attendance at the school, and Miss ROBERTSON the teacher, advised that the attendance of all had been very poor in the past. She considered however that the extremely wet day would no doubt account for the absence of many of the children.

I warned the children, present, as to the consequences of truancy, and that police action would result if the truancy continued. The teacher intimated that she believed that the warning so given, would probably have the desired effect for a time at least, and that she would again take the matter up with the Indian Agent, if the truancy continued.

I advised Mr. BRYANT of the action, taken and it was decided to take no further action this date. Should further complaints of this nature arise, warnings in writing will be given the various parents. The writer would respectfully request that this subject be taken up with the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, with a view to having a truant officer appointed for the Cote reserve district. This file is being considered closed at this time to be reopened in the event that further action by the Police is requested.

General;

Miss Robertson of Cote School fell down the basement steps and injured her hand, head and leg, and was unable to carry on her duties at Cote School for a couple of days. Miss Banfill arrived to act as missionary at Cote, but expected to do missionary work only, so did not stay. In the meantime Miss Robertson is doing her best to carry on with what help she can get. J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
Schools

Due to the man power shortage it has been necessary to get along as best we could with available teachers in our day schools, staffed by one of the church missions as they are. The first concern of the church mission is to supply a missionary, generally some one is chosen who is not much success in a parish and little thought is given to his or her ability as a teacher, and in most cases they have had no teacher experience and are anything but a success at the job. Under the present set up I doubt if we can ever hope to get the results that we should normally expect, and it is unfortunate for the children that spend several years at these schools seeking an education.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
I beg to submit herewith a report on the affairs of this Agency, for the quarter ending June 30th, 1946.

EDUCATION:

Miss Robertson of Cot Bay School has returned to her home and I understand will not return. She is a very fine woman and certainly did not spare herself trying to manage a very heavy school. However she has been in poor health and latterly the children became very difficult for her to handle, infact they were almost out of hand entirely. In the appointment of a successor I think we should insist on a male teacher, as I do not think there would be a bit of use sending another woman teacher for this difficult school. There is also to be a change at Key Bay school, and here again I hope we can have someone appointed that really knows something about teaching and the handling of Indian children. Nothing definite has been done about starting day school at Valley River. We may have to use some of the new catholic church for this purpose until we can build a school at a rental of $40.00 per month, but here again I would not recommend starting a day school there unless we can be assured that a male teacher that has some experience can be supplied for that point.

St Philips Residential school has built an addition to the present school and will be able to accommodate more pupils this coming term. This school is well managed, children are happy and on the whole parents are satisfied with the results.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Cote Indian Day School

In his report dated December 1, 1947, Mr. J. P. Gorczyński, School Inspector, makes the following comments concerning the above school:

"The minimum essentials of the curriculum are being adequately covered. The lessons are well prepared and effectively administered. The work in arithmetic is being presented in a simplified and meaningful form. The same psychologically sound method is employed in the presentation of other subjects in the course of study. The writing, reading, spelling, health and social studies receive additional emphasis.

"The library in this school is inadequate. A greater variety of simple and well illustrated reading material should be provided. Since the interests of the Indian children are somewhat different from their so-called white neighbors, the development of reading habits presents a problem and a challenge to the teacher.

"Hot noon lunches are being served in the school free of charge to the pupils. The allowance for noon meal made by the Department is absolutely insufficient. I would strongly suggest the increase in this allowance.

"The classroom is too overcrowded. It is strongly suggested that an additional classroom be provided for grades I and II class. It is absolutely impossible to do justice in this overcrowded classroom.

"Miss Johnson is continuing to give you good service."
You will recall that in the June issue of the Bulletin we published a long list of books selected from the supplementary reading lists of the various provincial departments of Education and which we had purchased for use in our Indian schools.

A search of our files indicates that we have no record of Miss Johnson ever having requisitioned for these books. Would you please bring this matter to her attention.

The provision of an extra classroom at this school has already been the subject of a letter dated December 5. It is to be hoped that the average attendance at this school remains high so that we can present a convincing argument for the addition of an extra classroom.

Rev. Sir,

I have been directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant in reference to a balance of salary due on account of the Cote Bay School.
