Ottawa, February 25, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. Jones, Treasurer of the Woman's Missionary Society, with reference to the amount of salary paid the teacher and matron at the Cote's Improved Indian Day School.

It is noted that she claims an unpaid balance of $222.75. This arises from the fact that beginning September 1st, last, a new teacher and a new matron were placed in charge of the Cote School. In computing salaries for the September quarter for new teachers the Department has been accustomed to pay on the basis which the number of days taught during that quarter bears to number of days in the school year. In the cases of Miss Sinclair and Mrs. McMillan the return showed that they were in charge for 17 days in the September quarter and, accordingly, the former was allowed 17/200 of $700.00, or, $63.75, and the latter 17/200 of $600.00, or, $51.00.

As the school year ends on June 30th, the Department has always made the necessary adjustments at that time and paid any arrears in salary that might be due. In the present case the balance of $222.75 would have been paid in June next.

For your information I enclose copy of the Indian Day School Regulations showing the procedure adopted. However, as possibly the Woman's Missionary Society desire this amount in order to close their books for the year 1921, a cheque for the balance due is being sent now instead of in June next.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. H. Edmison, D.D.,
Secretary,
Board Home Missions & Social Service,
Confederation Life Building,
Toronto, Ont.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from your Home Mission Convener for Kamsack Presbytery in which he states that Mrs. Marshall, teacher of the Cote Indian Day School, has submitted her resignation to take effect at the end of June, next. In reply I beg to say that the Department regrets that Mrs. Marshall has found it necessary to sever her connection with Indian school work, in which her services have been so satisfactory.

The Department will approve of the appointment of Mrs. D. R. Fraser, the present assistant, as teacher, from the beginning of the next school year. The total salary allowed her will be at the rate of $65 per month for the ten teaching months in the year.

Regarding the appointment of an assistant teacher and matron, the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Christina Templeton, whom Rev. Mr. McWhinney strongly recommends for the position. We are informing the local Indian Agent and Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, of the resignation of Mrs. Marshall and the appointment of Mrs. Fraser and Miss Templeton.

Balcarres, P. O., Sask., Nov. 30th, 1914

Dear Mr. Scott,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of October 1st, and other official correspondence with regard to the subject of a combination Day and Boarding school for Cote Reserve.

I am sending herewith a sketch of a proposed school, which has been prepared with great attention to details, and I think if this plan is followed it will suit our requirements. A school of this kind has been in my mind for a long time. Rev. Dr. Grant who was here yesterday looked over the plans and was well pleased with them.

You will notice that the building is to be heated with hot air, as this system is far more easily managed. Experience at File Hills school and elsewhere has led me to decide that for a building of this kind hot air is the most suitable.

The plumbing is worked out to meet all requirements allowing ample closets and bath-rooms.

I would draw your attention to the fact that the building is only 48' X 54' and still it provides room for 16 or 18 regular

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
regular boarders, for a married Principal (who should be teacher as well) and two of a staff. The dining-room and kitchen are large enough to provide for the additional pupils at the mid-day meal.

I am strongly of the opinion that the Principals of our Boarding schools should live in the building in order to look after the morals of the pupils and I have therefore provided quarters for the Principal in the building and am not sending a plan for an additional residence. Another reason for having the Principal living in the school proper is that as a Boarding school the grant earning power is extremely small and will not warrant keeping up a separate establishment.

The class-room should be a separate building similar to the one at File Hills. As you have plans of this in Ottawa, it will not be necessary to send a sketch.

I have tried to get away from the costly boarding school and at the same time provide a school that will meet all requirements on Cote reserve. All that will be necessary in the way of a staff will be a Principal (teacher also), a cook and a matron.

The cost of this building will be between twelve and fifteen thousand dollars.

Yours sincerely,

I beg to inform you that blue prints of the preliminary plans prepared for the combined Boarding and Day school, Cote Reserve, Sask., are being sent you by concurrent mail.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter above quoted, which remained unanswered until I had made a visit to Pelly, where I wished to get further information regarding the number of children that would likely attend the school it is proposed to build on Cote Reserve.

As you are aware, the Indians on Cote Reserve want a day school, and as I understand it, we are meeting their wishes half way by giving them a combination day and boarding school, that is to be managed by the Presbyterian church, on the per capita grant system. A school, such as we propose, will, at best, have only half the earning power a boarding school would have. It is therefore necessary to make the buildings as compact as possible, so as to run it with the least possible number of staff. So far as I can see at present we cannot hope to get more than 16 boarders and if I am right, it seems to me we might be able to curtail the building in some respects. Take the matter of infirmaries, do you not think that one room would answer the purpose?

From past experience at File Hills and other points, the space set aside for this purpose almost seems lost, as it is very rarely used. With the few children who will be living in

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
this school the necessity for such space will be correspondingly less and the chances are that boys and girls will not be sick at the same time. If only one room can be set aside it will mean something.

As the Principal will have to live in the building and will be a married man with possibly two children, I think a re-arrangement of the front rooms would be a great advantage. I think that on the right of the main entrance there should be two bed-rooms with closets and entrance between them, rooms, and the present sewing-room, which need not be very large, moved over to the left hand side to take the place of the corner bed-room.

Ground Floor:- I think it would be wise in view of the limited number of the staff to make the matter of supervision as easy as possible, and would suggest that the main passage be divided by a partition with a door; this would insure the complete separation of the boys and girls and would not necessitate a member of the staff being in constant attendance. In this matter we cannot be too particular, as we have had a great deal of trouble with boys and girls getting into each other's quarters, and now that we are putting up a government building, we should, if possible, make it so that this trouble can be avoided.

As the earning capacity of this school will be less than half what it is at the present Crowstand school, the staff must be just half what it is at present and if you can re-arrange the plan, doing away with one infirmary and making the dormitories much smaller, it
it would fill our requirements. Of course, if it were a boarding school we are going to build, we could add a few feet to the present plan and have a perfect building. But the Indians are pressing for a day school and all the accommodation we need is for sixteen children.

The staff accommodation as it now stands appears to be ample.

When it is decided to build great care should be taken as to the location of the building.

I would judge from the plans that there is to be no underground basement. Everything apparently is above ground. I presume the Department has its own reasons for having it done this way, but I have never seen a building of this kind without a basement.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter above quoted concerning the plans of the proposed Boarding and Day school at Cote Reserve.

The Indians of this reserve have been pressing for a Day school for a long time and have been led to believe that they would get one some day. The idea of a combination Day and Boarding school was suggested by the Presbyterian Church officers, and I am sure they had no idea of having such an elaborate building as the one for which you submitted plans. I must confess I was surprised when I saw them and the first idea that struck me was that we would be building a Boarding school and not a small combination school.

The plan I submitted was, in my opinion, too elaborate, if anything, but when I saw your plans, with additional rooms, extensive water system and extra bath-room I at once felt that the school could not be run on the grant from 12 or 16 pupils even with the additional Church grant.

I feel sure that on Cote's reserve there will not be sixteen Boarders, as the members of the Band are determined to have their children at home, but if we should have, say 14 Boarders, it seems to me that there ought to be some kind of a building that could be made to meet the requirements at very little cost.

Sir,

Acknowledging receipt of your letter of the 9th inst., No. 117-2-5 relative to table oilcloth and linoleum for the kitchen floor at the Cote Improved Day School, I beg to advise that both of these are necessary as what is now there in use is completely done.

In this connection I also beg to advise that the cost of linoleum will be approximately $19, which should last for several years, whereas previously was floor oilcloth which only lasted a very limited time. Linoleum will be much more permanent. With regard to the oilcloth for the tables this will cost in the neighborhood of 45¢ per yard and would suggest that another time this needs renewing to cover these tables with veneer and paint them which would be permanent except possibly a coat of paint once per year. While the expenditure would be out of the question this year I have however inquired into the cost which for veneer, placing and paint would cost in the neighborhood of $3.50 per table, the oilcloth of course is only around $1.50 but requires renewing each year.

In view of the necessity of both these may I have your authority to purchase the table oilcloth and linoleum, also your advice as to whether an item covering the cost of veneer and paint for this purpose should be placed in the estimates this year.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, requesting authority to purchase food supplies for the noonday meal and for resident pupils at the Cote Improved Indian Day School.

As our funds are extremely limited this year, it is necessary to enquire carefully into the cost of supplies for noonday meals. I have, therefore, to request that you will state the number of children who are resident in the school from Monday morning to Friday night. You should also state the distance from their homes to the school and if it would not be possible for them to reside at home and attend the school each day as day pupils. If it is not possible for them to travel to and from the school each day, you might state if arrangements could not be made to have them sent to either the Brandon or File Hills Indian Residential Schools. It is found that during the last school year the sum of approximately $200 was expended in the purchase of supplies for meals. We will be unable to provide this amount for the present school year. Please state the minimum amount per month which you consider would be required in the purchase of supplies for the noonday meal for the day pupils; also for the resident pupils, if it is necessary that the present arrangements for these latter pupils be continued. I shall be pleased to have, at an early date, as complete a report from you as possible regarding the continuing of the present arrangements and also as to the above suggestion that the pupils who are too far away to attend school each day be placed in a residential school.

In the meantime, you may arrange for the purchase of the quantity of food supplies considered absolutely necessary for the present month.

Dear Sir,-I have just been informed by Mr Agent McKenzie of the Pelty Indian Agency of a letter received recently from you in regard to expenditure at the Cote Indian School in which the following points were stressed?-

1. The expenditure of $200 during the past year for food supplies was too great and must be reduced.
2. It was asked if the pupils who have been boarding in the school from Monday until Friday could not go home each night and return in the morning.
3. It was also asked if these pupils could not be transferred to the boarding schools at File Hills or Brandon.

Now as supervisor of this school for The United Church of Canada I would urge that there be no reduction in the necessary supplies for the Cote School in order to provide fittingly for the few pupils who lodge and board there from Monday until Friday. Also while we do not object to pupils being transferred to these boarding schools if the parents so desire, we do not think any undue pressure should be brought to bear to bring this about.

There has been, I think considerable change of late years in the officials of the Department and perhaps you are not aware of the conditions and the understanding under which the Cote school was built in 1915. At that time the Presbyterian Church agreed to the closing of the Crowstand Boarding School which had previously supplied educational facilities to these reserves, with the understanding that a semi-boarding and day school would be erected on the reserve. The plans for such a school were drawn but suddenly the Department decided instead to build an improved day school. From 1916 until 1928 this was conducted as a simple day school where the pupils received a warm mid-day meal. At that time the Department erected the St Philips Boarding School five miles away and at once the Roman Catholic Church began to encroach and try to entice the pupils from our day school. To secure a small degree of equality of school opportunity we secured the consent of the Department to board several pupils, from a distance, from Monday till Friday. I urged that we be given additional lodging accommodation but was refused. The injustice of the situation lay in the fact that a large and costly boarding school was erected for one Church and the other was refused the expenditure of a few hundred dollars to provide for the needs of a few pupils who were too far away to attend as day pupils. Since then we have been utilizing some extra space to accommodate not more than five or six pupils. Last year and now there are only three or four. It costs the Department $150 to $160 to maintain a pupil in a boarding school. I ask you is it reasonable to object to an expenditure of something like $200 to maintain three or four pupils for the year. I am heartily in accord with any effort to save money where it can be saved without inflicting hardship but the Cote school is not the place to cut down expenses. The matron makes good use of all the supplies received and there should be no curtailment. Further, these pupils live too far away to allow them to attend merely as day pupils.

Commending these matter to your consideration, I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

Sir,

Replying to your letter No.117-2-5 of the 8th inst., regarding supplies for the Cote Day School, I beg to advise that at present there are only two resident pupils there, both from the Keeskonse reserve, nine miles distant. The Protestant families on that reserve raise an objection to sending their children to File Hills when there is a boarding school, (St. Philips, R.C.) on their reserve. If we had any way of forcing them to send their children away, there would be no need of boarding any pupils at the Cote School during the week, except for the noon day meal. This was the very reason for keeping resident pupils at Cote as the Indians there who were protestants turned R.C. rather than send their children away and these people are still of the same opinion. I would much prefer to see resident pupils not kept at the Cote School as they haven't proper facilities there to do so, but run into this same objection by the parents as soon as they are approached regarding sending them to File Hills.

In working out on a per capita basis the amount of the supplies for meals $200, for last year, it cost less than 5¢ per capita for these supplies per day, so it could not be lowered unless we were to dispense with the noon day meal entirely, and also the resident pupils.

Your obedient servant,

PLUMBING, HEATING
AND TINSMITHING

KAMSACK, SASK. 17th, May, 1933

E.A.W.R. McKenzie Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Re heating plant Cote Indian School

In accordance with your request, I beg to report that on April 25th last I made a thorough examination of the above heating plant and find as follows:

1. The cast iron fire box of furnace is cracked in several places, these cracks have opened to the extent of half an inch and in rear end there are several pieces of casting on the point of falling out, in fact if the wood used for firing is not carefully placed in fire box, the end would be completely knocked out in a short time. The openings in fire box also create a continuous fire hazard as the suction of the air circulating through the warm air passages will tend to draw the sparks from the fire box and deliver them through the hot air registers into the rooms above.

2. The grates in the fire box are also burned out.

3. The brick work around the top and at the front of furnace is cracked and in several places has fallen out, the joints in the radiator drums also require to be cemented with furnace cement and one direct draft damper installed.

I might add that this furnace was overhauled and reinstalled in 1923 and the ten years service since has completely burned out the fire box and other parts which cannot be replaced as this furnace is obsolete and it is impossible to procure any repairs except grates, consequently it will be impossible to begin another winters firing with the furnace in this condition, in fact it is nothing short of a miracle that there has not already been a fire.

It has also been reported to me that the distribution of hot air in the building is very unsatisfactory as notwithstanding a strong fire it is impossible to heat that part of the building exposed to the wind and it would not be advisable to replace the present furnace with one of the same type and installed under similar con-
E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Indian Agent.

ditions as this will not improve the distribution of hot air and would recommend that a steam heating plant be installed as it will then be possible to place the heat where it will be most effective and not be affected by winds.

I would be pleased to submit estimate of cost for installing same

Yours truly,

Sir:

The Department has had recent correspondence with Mr. Agent McKenzie, Kamsack, Sask., regarding the heating equipment at the Cote Indian Day School. He reports that the cost of a new hot air furnace, using the present pipes for hot air and registers, would be approximately $300.

No doubt, you will be in the Pelly agency in the near future, and I would request that you visit this school, inspect the present heating equipment and report what you would advise be done at the lowest possible expense in order to provide for the heating of the building during the coming winter. The Superintendent General of Indian Education

Dear Sir,

About the end of the month of June Mr Agent McKenzie of the Belly Indian Agency showed me a letter which he had received saying it was the intention of the Department to cut off certain food supplies from the Cote Bay School. We were not just clear as to whether this meant the cutting off of all food supplies or only those for the few boarding pupils who remain in the school from Monday till Friday.

Since this same matter was under consideration about a year ago I would ask you to look up on your files my letter of September 14th 1932 and your reply of September 24th. This letter of mine, I think shows very clearly that the conditions under which the Cote School was established and the excellent work it has done since entitles it to special considerations. Further, it should be remembered that the action of the Department in erecting the St Philips School five miles away makes it imperative that no action be taken which would interfere with the Cote School meeting the needs of its proper constituency.

If these food supplies are cut off it means that a considerable number of these pupils would be transferred to residential schools. It should not be necessary for me to point out that these children are being educated in the Cote School in a much more economical way than they could be in a residential school where each would cost in the neighborhood of $150.00 per year. But if economy is the aim of the Department such action would mean increased rather than lessened expenditure.

For many years I have held that the policy of the Department should move towards the day school system replacing the residential schools and thus leading the Indian parents to assume a greater responsibility for the support and upbringing of their children. In a recent conversation with Honourable Mr. Murphy he quite agreed with me in this policy and asked me to write the Department in regard to the Cote School matter.

I would therefore urge most strongly that there be no lessening of the providing of food supplies for the Cote School. At present the parents are bearing a goodly share of the support of their children and at the present time to attempt to lay any heavier burden upon them would lead to injury and not benefit. You can depend upon it that as supervisor of this School and Missionary on the Reserve I am each year exacting as much self-support as possible from the Indian parents. Such a gradual advance we hope some day will lead the Indian to assume the same responsibility as our own people.

Commending this whole matter to your sympathetic consideration,

I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

Referring to Department letter No. 117-2-5, dated June 19th last, with reference to the heating equipment at the Cote Indian Day School in the Pelly Agency, I beg to inform you that I have just completed an inspection of the Pelly Agency and while there I visited the Cote Day School and made a thorough examination of the heating plant.

The school staff were all absent on their vacation. I however managed to gain access to the furnace room. I found that the condition of this furnace is very bad. As a matter of fact I consider it unsafe to have a fire placed in it. The cast iron fire box is burned out. It is cracked in several places at the sides and some of these cracks have opened nearly one half inch. There are openings at the rear of the furnace and several pieces of casing are on the point of falling out. A jar such as might easily happen by throwing a stick of wood in too far would knock the whole end of the furnace out. As it is, I could see plainly into the hot air chamber. These openings in the fire box create a continuous fire hazard, as the air circulating through the surrounding air passage will tend to draw the sparks from the fire box and deliver them through the hot air registers into the room above. In my opinion the fire box is beyond repair and unsafe for further use. A new furnace is, in my opinion, absolutely necessary if the school is to be continued. I would not take the responsibility of operating that school during the winter months until the heating equipment is put in order. The estimate of $300.00 is very reasonable.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Sir,

I beg to advise that of the amount of $125.00 authorized for the purchase of food for the Gote Day School in Department letter No.117-2-5 of Aug. 9th last, approximately $214.00 of the amount has been expended, which amount includes $6.55 covering items purchased for cleaning, such as soap, bon ami &c. This leaves a balance of $11.00 for the school's requirements in the food line to last until the end of the academic year, June 30th next. The school is going to experience difficulty in getting through until the holidays as they will be unable to purchase meat as well as other supplies on the balance.

At present the children are being fed on bread, potatoes and rice pudding.

Could this be supplemented by meat being supplied until the school closes in June next?

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs.
Kamsack, April 13th 1934.

Mr A. F. McKenzie,
Secretary of Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

Under date of August 4th last year I wrote you pointing out several important reasons why the appropriation for supplies to the Cote School should not be reduced. You replied saying that you were allowing $125.00 for supplies for the year 1933 and 34. But during the year certain other supplies than food such as soap etc. that were formerly supplied from the Agency have been cut off and these also had to be charged up against the $125. Then too the attendance at the Cote School has been larger during this year than the previous one when the allowance was $150. Hence at the present time with two months and a half yet to run before the end of the year there is only something like $11.00 left to provide for three or four boys in residence for five days of the week and provide for the mid day meal of about twenty-five other children. You will readily see what an impossible task you are placing upon the matron of the school and what a menace such curtailment of food means to these children. In a letter to Mr Agent McKenzie you suggest that meat should not be required for the children during the summer. Now if you consider that Indian children more than many others require a certain amount of meat in their diet in order that they be maintained in health, you will realize how unjust it would be to treat these children in this way. By the treaties made with the Indians the Government of Canada has placed itself under certain moral obligations, aside from the legal obligations, to educate the Indian children. In the residential schools provision is made not only for boarding them in a fitting manner but also for clothing them. Surely an Improved Day School should demand sufficient suitable food stuffs to give these children one satisfying meal during the day. I was Principal of a residential school for fourteen years and I have been supervisor under our Church of this Cote School for seventeen years, and I cannot see why children in a day school where the Indian parent bears the large part of their maintenance should not receive fair and reasonable treatment for one meal in the day.

Mrs Roy, the matron is careful in all her management. There is no waste but she has a mother heart and she should not be asked to set Indian children down to a meal of which she is ashamed. Furthermore these children cannot properly do their work in the class room if they are hungry. Such a condition is not creditable to the Government of this Dominion.

Instead of crowding the day schools to the wall, it seems to me the policy of the Department should be to increase their efficiency to such an extent that in time they would to a great extent take the place of the much more costly residential schools.

I am in thorough sympathy with every proper move towards economy but I am quite sure there are many other places where economy can be practised with much better results than in cutting down the already meagre allowance to this school. I would ask that Mr Agent McKenzie be notified at once to procure meat and such other supplies as are necessary to maintain the school properly to the end of the term.

Trusting that this matter will meet with a favourable and sympathetic reception from you, I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

Memorandum:

The Honourable the Superintendent General:-

I am returning Rev. Mr. McWhinney's letter of the 23rd ultimo.

At the Cote Indian Day School, there is an average attendance of approximately 25 children, and the Department has for many years found it difficult to satisfy the demands made by Mr. McWhinney. When it was necessary to reduce expenditures, department officials considered that $125 would be an adequate amount for midday meal purposes at this school for the academic year 1933-34. I find that, since last September, accounts have been submitted amounting to approximately $85. This means that some $30 can still be expended without exceeding the amount which the Department promised. I may add that, in addition to this expenditure, the school has been supplied with 800 pounds of biscuits, 13 sacks of flour, and 50 pounds of rice. Under these circumstances, I feel you will agree that the expenditure that has been authorized is fairly adequate.

I am of the opinion that Mr. McWhinney's reason for urging increased expenditure for food supplies is partly due to the fact that, without the Department's approval, three or four children, whose parents live at a considerable distance from the school, are kept in residence at the Day School and, consequently, have to be supplied with all their meals.

I trust that the attached letter will meet with your approval.

Dr Magill,
Deputy Sect. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Last Spring I had some correspondence with Hon. T. G. Murphy in regard to the amount of money allowed the Cote Day School for food supplies for the noon day meal and also for the maintenance of the five or six pupils who lodge and board at the school from Monday until Friday. I urged that for this academic year that at least $150.00 be allowed. Some time ago I was informed by the Indian Agent Mr McKenzie that only $125.00 had been allowed. Then more recently I was told that the supply of beef formerly supplied from the Agency stores was to be supplied no longer. Now I have understood that it was the policy of the Department to encourage the Day School form of Indian education to such an extent that some time in the future it would largely supplant the work done in the residential schools. If this is so I cannot understand why such treatment as referred to above is meted out to the Cote School which means trying to crowd it out of existence.

I would therefore ask your attention to the following features in this matter:

1. There are about thirty pupils to be given a mid-day meal and five pupils to be fed from Monday until Friday.
2. Meat is an important item of diet for an Indian child and pupils in residential schools are supposed to have meat at least once a day.
3. Owing to weather conditions the school potato crop was almost a failure and forty or fifty bushels of potatoes will have to be purchased out of the amount allowed for food.
4. If these five pupils in residence from Monday until Friday were sent to a residential school it would cost the Department in per capita grant $750.
5. Is this economy to force these children to a residential school?

The matron in the Cote School is exceedingly careful in the use of all supplies but surely it is not fair to ask her to do the impossible or to see these children underfed and their health suffer in consequence.

For about fifteen years I was principal of a residential school and for thirty-one years I have been missionary on this Reserve. For the past eighteen years I have been supervisor of the Cote School for the Women's Missionary Society and feel that I can speak with some authority in regard to the matter of the treatment of Indian children.

I am in hearty sympathy with every effort of the Department along the lines of economy but it is a pity to see economy misplaced and I feel that this is decidedly the case in this matter of supplies for the Cote School.

I would urge therefore that the school receive its supply of beef from the Agency stores as formerly and that the amount allowed for other supplies be increased from $125.00 to at least $150.00. Surely this is an insignificant amount in comparison with what is spent on the residential schools.

Trusting that this matter will receive your sympathetic attention, I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Your letter of the 17th came to hand some days ago and I note that you say that since the estimates for the Department for the current year had been reduced and that you had made the increase from $125.00 to $150 for the maintenance of the Cote School you were of the opinion that you had dealt reasonably well with this School.

Now with all due respect for the degree of familiarity which yourself and others in the Department have with the different Indian Schools permit me to say that since none of you have ever visited this School I do not think you fully understand the conditions and the very creditable work that is being done or you would not hesitate to grant very much more than I have been asking.

Sometimes I wonder if there is someone locally who is influencing your judgment in this matter or if there is an underlying desire and purpose to crowd out this school in order to give wider scope and opportunity to some boarding school. It does seem very strange that per capita grants of $150 are paid to boarding schools and here we are maintaining a school for $150 of a grant which cares for thirty children. Is it then asking too much when we ask for sufficient extra to buy a beef animal to supply beef to the children? Is it creditable to the Department that the matron has to send the boys out to snare rabbits to furnish the children of wards of the Government of Canada with a little meat?

As I said in my former letter I am in hearty sympathy with everything that makes for economy but there are right and wrong places for its exercise. I venture to say there is not an Agency in the West where many times fifteen dollars is spent in far less needful ways than in providing proper food for these children. When I say this I am speaking of that which I know to be fact.

Now I hope you will not think I am over persistent in this matter but when I know positively that I am asking only for what is right and reasonable I shall not drop this matter until I have made every effort to have the Department see this business somewhat as I do. I hope however that the good sense of Hon. T. G. Murphy as well as the Deputy Minister and yourself will see that justice is done without continuing this correspondence any further.

I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, No. 117-2-5, in connection with the electric current supplied to the Cote Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that I received no authority for the installation of the current in this school. The current had been supplied the school from the time that the Delco plant was first installed at the Agency, and I assumed that, as the Kamsack power was taking the place of the old Delco plant for the remainder of the lighting, and there was no further expense in connection with the installation, no additional authority was required in connection with the lighting of the school.

If it is not the intention of the Department to furnish light to this school it is only necessary to disconnect the wires.

The Department originally paid for the wiring of this school. In the Auditor General's Report for this Agency for the fiscal year 1929-30 there is a charge of $1850 for installing a Delco plant and $1000 of this was charged to the Education Vote, apparently referring to the Cote Day School as that is the year the plant was installed at the Agency and the day school wired.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report of a visit which I made to the Cote Indian Day School in the Pelly Agency on the 14th instant.

Miss Ruby M. Jamieson has been in charge of the classroom as teacher since November last. She has a First Class certificate for Saskatchewan. I was very favorably impressed with her. She appears capable, has good control over her pupils, and her class organization appears to be good and I consider her work is very satisfactory.

There were 23 Indian pupils present out of an enrollment of 27. In addition to these, two of the Indian Agents and three of the Farming Instructors children attend regularly. The attendance has been good during the present quarter, with the exception of the last week in January and the first week in February when an epidemic of influenza reduced it. Apart from these two weeks the daily attendance has been from 18 to 23, which is very good considering the unusually severe weather we have had since the New Year.

I found the classroom clean and tidy. The children presented a healthy and clean appearance and they appeared to be warmly clothed.

This is what is called an Improved Day School. There is a matron in charge, Mrs. Roy, who prepares a mid-day meal for the Indian children. Mrs. Roy is a good housekeeper and takes an interest in the welfare of the children.

I made an examination of the building and wish to draw the Department's attention to the condition of the basement foundation. It is very badly cracked and daylight can be seen through the cracks. The result is that, notwithstanding there is a hot air furnace in this basement, the temperature of the basement is below freezing point on the day of my visit. With conditions such as this you will understand that it is difficult to heat the building. An item has been placed in the Estimates for 1926-27 to cover the cost of repairing this basement wall and I would strongly recommend that the work be done during the coming summer. I consider this important, as at present it endangers the condition of the building as well as making it uncomfortable.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

It is further noted that the matron, who prepares the midday meal for the pupils, takes an active interest in their welfare.

Regarding the condition of the basement foundation, I have to say, for your information, that the following items are provided in our Estimates for the coming fiscal year for this school:

Dear Sir:

As previously reported to the Department, and provisions made in the estimates therefor, the foundation of the Cote Day School building is in bad shape.

As a result of this, the cistern, for storing rain water, was burst by frost during the extremely cold weather of the past winter. I have examined this cistern and I do not think it is worth repairing. It was made of galvanized iron about twenty years ago and the metal is about at the end of its usefulness. It is located close to the fuel chute and the outside entrance door, and as a consequence is in the coldest part of the basement. It should be on the other side of the furnace, where the basement is warmer and, to move it there, it would have to be taken down.

I would recommend that a new cistern be made and placed in the proper location in the basement. The cost of material and labour would be about $50.00. This would include labour to make minor changes in the eaves-troughing, which would be necessary in changing the location of the cistern.

As you are aware, the water situation at this school is not good and, when there is no water stored in the cistern, it is necessary for all the washing water to be hauled from the river to the school, a distance of about half a mile. I would be glad if authority could be given me for this expenditure as soon as possible after the first of April, in order that the cistern can be completed in time to catch any early rain-fall.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 31, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, the Department has provided in the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1936-37 an amount of $200 for rebuilding the foundation and basement walls of the Cote Bay School. On the recommendation of Inspector Murison, who visited this school on February 14th, it was decided not to proceed with this work until the summer holidays.

In addition to the amount stated above, we will have available another amount for painting, but it is not the Department's intention to do any exterior painting this year owing to lack of funds. Consequently, if the repairs to the foundation will cost more than $200, part of the money provided for painting could be used.

If you consider that any repairs that may be made to the foundation and basement walls during the summer holidays will not damage the new cistern, which you recommend be installed at once, you may proceed with the latter work. It is noted from your letter that the cost of the material and labour for the new cistern will be approximately $50.00.

Yours truly,
